output: Many thanks, Mr. President. I strongly welcome the approach we describe in the White Paper, which aims to get to the root causes of malnutrition and obesity and the resulting diseases.
Unfortunately, in food policy in Europe, whether we are discussing nutrient profiles, food labeling, or even certain sections of the White Book, we tend to adopt a highly one-sided approach.
In fact, we are attempting to resolve the issues we face in Europe through product policy.
I believe it is fundamentally flawed policy to assume that there are good and bad foods.
Many amendments illustrate this. It does not exist.
There are only good and bad, or rather balanced and unbalanced, ways of nutrition.
This should be our approach.
The causes of malnutrition are multifaceted.
Attempting to rectify this by guiding the consumer through product labeling, or even through advertising bans, regulations, or varying VAT rates, will not achieve our goal.

I believe that everything we are doing here, without wanting to preempt the debate on labeling regulations, should fall under the heading: What can we do to motivate consumers to reflect on their dietary habits?
A traffic-light labeling system that suggests to him "I am now facing a good or bad product" is, in my opinion, more an instrument of disempowerment than one of education and enlightenment.
Therefore, I advocate for a more balanced approach here and the realization that relying solely on product policy will not take us any further. Thank you.

Madam President, Vice-President, dear colleagues,

Budget control has no new topics.
We are content with the old and would also be satisfied with progress on the old topics.
Five points, firstly, our urgent request for support for Romania and Bulgaria in building up the rule of law, the judiciary, and financial control.
We do not want to be where we are today in two years' time, which is why this point is of utmost importance to us.
The second point is the Reliability Declaration for the overall budget following the graduated control procedure, involving the national audit courts.
It would be desirable if we could make decisive progress in the last six months remaining to the Commission, or at least agree on a common path.
One does become modest as a household controller.
The third point would be simplification.
We need to provide more support to the lower administrative levels of the member states in the implementation of EU law.
It becomes apparent that they are completely overwhelmed by large parts of EU law, which is why the high error rates occur.

The fourth point: External Assistance

Here, I would like to address the Kosovo in particular and the issue of cooperation with the United Nations.
The Committee on Budgetary Control has been to Kosovo. I would like to announce in advance that Kosovo will play a certain role in the discharge of the budget.
I believe that we have remained far below the capabilities of the European Union thus far and that we urgently need to catch up on our efforts in this area.
The fifth point would be the improvement of cooperation among member states in the fight against fraud.
We have homework here, primarily for the ladies and gentlemen of the Council.
The Parliament will vote on the legal basis, the regulation for fraud prevention, in November, and then we must jointly consider how to proceed if we want to achieve better results in this field.
At least, that has been our shared desire until now.
Mr. President. India and Europe need more and better contacts at all levels, especially also at the level of so-called ordinary people.
Business travelers, tourists, students, etc. A brief note on this: It also has relevance for the Commission's legislative program, which we discussed earlier.
In global air traffic, we need good safety regulationsâ€”ones that are effective and not just token measures.
It would therefore be a reasonable and truly necessary measure to finally abolish the pointless liquid regulations and come up with something better.
I voted for the resolution because it is a clear call to the Belarusian government to finally respect human rights.

It is disappointing that the hopes for a democratic development for the people of this last European dictatorship were not fulfilled with the questionable, indeed rigged, parliamentary elections of September.
The same applies to the strategic suppression of the opposition and civil society.
At the same time, we have today called on the Council and the Commission to facilitate and intensify contacts between people and to democratize the country by seriously exploring the possibility of
Consider reducing visa fees for Belarusian citizens when entering the Schengen area to prevent the increasing isolation of Belarus and its citizens.
First of all, I would like to refute the notion, expressed just a few minutes ago, that foreigners are flooding the labor market, our labor market.
Secondly, I would have liked a clearer and more unambiguous report from the Employment Committee.
Trust in the social binding force of the European Union can only be achieved if fundamental social rights are defined as primary European law.

We should send a stronger signal to the Council, the Commission, the Member States, and the ECJ, and not be content with merely calling for a balance between fundamental rights and internal market freedoms and free movement.
By doing so, we are not changing anything. Social fundamental rights are, just like freedom rights, human rights that must not be restricted by the freedoms of the internal market.
It is about defending and improving the European social model, and it is high time for the introduction of a social progress clause as a binding protocol to the existing EU treaties.
It is time to amend the Posted Workers Directive so that wage and minimum standards requirements are not limited to minimum requirements.
Mr. President. I would like to associate myself with the expressions of gratitude to the rapporteur, Doris Pack, which have already been rightly conveyed by many of my colleagues.
We have someone in her who hopefully does not shed blood, sweat, and tears, but invests a great deal of passion and effort into this space.
I am delighted with her and the colleagues who also stated this, that there have been some advancements, particularly in the field of police cooperation.
This is important to ensure that real life on the ground can function in a reasonable manner.

I still believe, however, that we must continually remind our conversation partners in Bosnia and Herzegovina that a great deal more needs to be contributed by you, by your side, perhaps even more than is currently being contributed in some areas.
Internal collaboration, the willingness to engage in this internal collaboration within ethnicities, is something we must continually demand.
It is not the case that everyone tries to go their own way.
And integration into regional cooperation in the Western Balkans is also important.
Madam President. The distance between the European Union and its citizens must not grow as much as it has.
We need to ensure that it is reduced in size.
In this context, the ombudsman has an important role to play, especially when and where he performs it well.
It is also primarily about ensuring that we have the commitment and discretion of the ombudsman.
It is about not raising expectations too high that no one can then meet.

It is also about ensuring that, wherever shortcomings have occurred in the administration of the European institutions, these are addressed and, where possible, reasonable solutions are sought that can then guarantee and satisfy the citizen.
Previous practice has shown that the Ombudsman fulfills this task diligently and competently.
We can hope that this remains the case and thank him and the rapporteur for this report.
Yes.
Dear colleagues, ten years after the realization of the monetary union, Europe finds itself in a severe crisis.
Banks are collapsing or being propped up with billions from the national treasury, sales are plummeting, and millions of people fear for their jobs and their future.
But it is not just the market that has failed; the prevailing political system also seems incapable of learning from its mistakes.

We are of the opinion that even with such interjections you do not particularly wish to distinguish yourself. We believe that serious mistakes were made in the construction of the Economic and Monetary Union.
Such an error is the structural decoupling of monetary and fiscal policy. One cannot create a common currency without at least partially harmonizing tax and expenditure policies at the same time.
I believe that the economic imbalances in the Eurozone have intensified enormously.
What we need now is indeed better coordination of economic and, in particular, tax policy.
We need effective measures against tax dumping, in addition, tax havens must be closed and capital flows finally brought under control again.
The second significant error lies in the construction of the Stability and Growth Pact.

Anyone who believes that household consolidation is unavoidable in times like these is clearly living in a different world. Nothing would be more fatal than to respond to this economic crisis by now also implementing public austerity programs.
The Stability Pact has unequivocally demonstrated its failure.
It should be replaced by an integrated European strategy for solidarity and sustainable development.
In our view, what is needed is an investment offensive to renew public infrastructure and improve the situation of socially disadvantaged people in Europe.
A third error lies in the construction of the European Central Bank itself, which is subject to no democratic control and is committed solely to the goal of price stability.

We advocate for democratic control of the European Central Bank, and furthermore, we demand a correction of the ECB's monetary policy mandate, ensuring that in the future, growth and employment are promoted as equally as price stability.
The current crisis also presents an opportunity for far-reaching reforms of the European monetary and financial architecture.
This opportunity should not be squandered lightly.
Madam President, Commissioner, President-in-Office of the Council, esteemed colleagues. Indeed, the automotive industry is in crisis, and there are many reasons for this.
In particular, the financial crisis has further exacerbated the crisis in this sector, and member states are currently working on solutions.
The European automotive industry is a key industry.
And therefore, for this key European industry, we also need European solutions to overcome the crisis.
Nearly all automotive conglomerates exhibit European structures.

To be able to make necessary investments in environmentally friendly cars, as has been mentioned several times here today, and in technologies that are both environmentally friendly and fuel-efficient, automakers require public guarantees or low-interest loans from the European Investment Bank.
But the supplier industry, which would be of utmost importance, must not be forgotten in this context.
It is particularly in the supplier industry, in small and medium-sized enterprises, that jobs are being created and where innovations are taking place.
But what can the European Union do to protect this key industry?
At the last plenary session, the President of the Council proposed a measure to protect key industries.
A good proposal, in my opinion. If we consistently follow this proposal to its conclusion, it means a Volkswagen Law for the entire European automotive industry.
and this would certainly be a good instrument.
But this protection instrument is currently being opposed by the European Commission.
And so my question to the Commission is: Will the European Commission, despite the crisis in the automotive industry, maintain its legal action, or will it now change course in light of the crisis?

Dear Mr. President, Mr. President of the European Court of Auditors, Mr. Vice-President of the European Commission, dear colleagues,

Indeed, it has now become a tradition to note that,
It must be noted that in the relationship between expenditures at the European level and administration at the national level, a declaration of reliability cannot be issued repeatedly.

I recall conversations with the former President of the Court of Auditors, Professor Friedmann, who once told me that, due to the structures in place, it is absolutely impossible to provide a reliability statement.
Therefore, we should already think together about how this instrument can be brought to life in such a way that the goal of a reliability declaration, when justified, can also be achieved.
And here we must, of course, distinguish between a few things.
Firstly, a budget that encompasses around five and ninety subsidies is much more susceptible to fraud than a national, regional, or municipal budget.

A subsidy budget, which is essentially managed by the member states, who have indeed demanded much more autonomy from us in the new financial period, as the criticism of the last funding period was that it was too centrally controlled.
This of course also means that responsibility for the money must be taken on at regional and national levels.
And I would like to briefly touch upon a third area of discussion.
We must also learn to distinguish between fraud and waste.
These, too, are things that are often lumped together.
I am also annoyed when things that are not strictly necessary are funded with EU money.
That, however, was not fraud, it was waste.

Therefore, those responsible for the projects, particularly in the field of structural policy, also have the responsibility, together with the Member States, to ensure that money is not wasted and that only those projects are supported that genuinely create added value for the region.
Therefore, we should certainly also consider converting parts of structural policy to interest-free loans.
If member states have to repay, then they will only promote what they really need. Thank you very much.
It is not just me who finds it difficult to join in the emerging self-praise of European decision-makers when it comes to managing the financial market crisis.
goes to show that if this EU were a functioning democracy, one would first have to ask the question of responsibility and how all this could have come about.
It is simply not true that all the problems we now face are like a tsunami, a natural phenomenon, but rather they are man-made.
Amidst all the regulatory fervor that this Union has unleashed, one wonders why action was not taken when banks began crossing national borders on a significant scale?
Why was no action taken, despite appropriate warnings, as derivatives became so insidiously integrated?
I well remember that your Nobel laureate Josef Stiglitz addressed all these points.
There was silence, there was a taboo.
One should start there, because the key to finding solutions in the future lies solely in recognizing one's own mistakes.
Mr. President, esteemed ladies and gentlemen. Commissioner, my question concerns your opinion on Iceland and Hungary introducing the euro as a secondary currency.
Do you believe that this could solve the problem between these two countries?
The second question is: Do you believe it would be possible to introduce a risk premium for derivatives, which could then be used to strengthen the banks' equity?
My third question is: Don't you think that a reduction in value-added tax would accordingly support imports, especially from China and India?
Would it not be more reasonable to consider tax reductions for our businesses and, for our employees, to pay investment premiums, and to correspondingly increase depreciation in the...

The focus is on increasing the value of low-worth economic goods by a factor of 10, ensuring that fictitious profits are not taxed, that money remains within the enterprises, and that wages can thus be better paid.
Madam President. The comprehensive report makes it clear how many human rights violations occur around the world every single day.
This is particularly alarming sixty years after the declaration of the Universal Declaration of Human Rights, and it calls on us to redouble our efforts.
For this reason as well, I would like to advocate for the current Sub-Committee on Human Rights to be established as a Main Committee.
Today, we awarded the Sakharov Prize to Anhu Jia, who advocates for human rights and the environment in China.
Because he is incarcerated, he was unable to assume personal responsibility.
Shame on China, and tomorrow a debate on human rights violations in Russia will take place here.
In our relations with these two countries, we must give not only economic interests but especially human rights a higher priority.
We demand freedom for Hu Jia in China and freedom for Mikhail Khodorkovsky in Russia.

Mr. President, esteemed members of the Council, Commissioner, dear colleagues,

As the rapporteur for the Anti-Fraud Office, one makes interesting experiences, such as the fact that everyone talks about fighting fraud and then no one does anything.
or the experience that Member States calculate their payments to the European Union with a sharp pencil, but put on their spending pants when it comes to disbursing this money.
and it even makes it easy for fraudsters, for example, by taking an average of thirty-six months to report irregularities to the European Union for the first time.
The European Parliament does not agree with this.
We aim for efficient fraud prevention, which includes proactive measures.
We aim for member states to prioritize fraud prevention and for us to collectively discuss the requirements and challenges associated with it.
We aim to foster greater interest among national judicial authorities in pursuing OLAF investigation outcomes.
In Kromenturen, there must no longer be legal vacuums as has been the case hitherto.
We need to equate European money with national money.
We want an independent agency that has the necessary resources and legal foundations to fulfill its tasks.
And we want an agency that can cooperate seamlessly and efficiently with the member states.
Our position on the legal basis provides for all these points.
We advocate for further developing this regulation, as the cornerstone of the Anti-Fraud Office, in collaboration with the Council.
We call on the Council to incorporate our opinion, and we urge the Council to initiate discussions on the further development of this regulation.
We aim to bring the problems of OLAF to a resolution.
I thank all the factions of the House for also supporting this in a resolution, which we will vote on tomorrow.
I appeal to the French and Czech presidencies of the Council to pick up the ball thrown by Parliament and return it.
In our proposals, we have also incorporated solutions developed and presented by the Council Working Group.
From our side, I can express our interest in a swift conclusion to this regulation and assure you of our willingness to engage in constructive discussions based on our proposals.
Consolidating all OLAF legal bases, as the Council has indeed planned, would mean a further significant loss of time with an uncertain outcome.
Ola will soon celebrate his tenth birthday.
A consolidation means another ten years without an improved legal basis.
We take fraud prevention too seriously for that.
We therefore aim to implement what is feasible now, in cooperation with the Council.
Sincere thanks.
Mr. President. I would like to pick up on a remark made earlier by my Austrian colleague, Paul RÃ¼big.

We spend less than one percent of the European gross domestic product on Europe, while at the same time demanding that an ever-increasing number of tasks for an ever-growing number of member states be addressed by the European Union.
This calculation cannot add up. It is therefore also highly implausible that we have been pursuing a course of austerity for many years, but that this austerity is not reflected in a frugal approach.
Our funds are not being used for their intended purpose, but rather to enable finance ministers to collect money at the end of the year and incorporate it into their national budgets.
We have enough new tasks for which we should spend our money.
We also have tasks that we have not actually funded adequately in budgetary terms for years.
I believe that the European Union's information funds should be significantly increased if we truly want to engage European citizens with Europe.
And there are many tasks in the area of student and apprentice exchanges where Europe could deploy its resources.
that democracy is also making progress in the justice sector, a field that has traditionally been a reserved domain of the state.
This reflects the changed living conditions of the people in our Union.
But this remark has already been made several times: Integration must not interfere too much with traditionally established and, above all, functioning structures.
Not everything should be judged by the same yardstick.
Public deeds and public deed officials are designed quite differently in many member states.
In Austria, but not only in our country, the notariat as a public office of record has a long tradition and a high level of security and trust.
This should not be put at risk unnecessarily, just because such professional groups do not exist elsewhere.
Therefore, integration and mutual openness yes, but with a sense of proportion.
Madam President, esteemed colleagues. Pesticides were and remain essential operational tools in agriculture.
Farmers require a minimum selection of pesticides, as it concerns the protection of the domestic cultivated landscape, high-quality nutrition, and the preservation of resources.
We often conduct discussions about chemicals at a highly irrational level.
To obtain reasonable results, however, we must think and act rationally.
The impact of the original parliamentary position would have been fatal: a broad ban on pesticides would have resulted in lower agricultural yields and, ultimately, rising food prices.
Therefore, I am pleased that a barely acceptable compromise was reached in the trilogue negotiations.
It is welcome that we have maintained the Three-Zone Regulation, albeit with significant exceptions for member states.

A bold step towards a consistent internal market solution would look different at this point. In addition to acceptable compromises, we should not preempt a final definition of endocrine-disrupting substances but actually give the EU Commission the four years to present a scientifically based definition.
Otherwise, we are stretching the precautionary principle beyond its limits at this point.
And lastly, I regret that we are not tempted to initiate a consequential impact assessment of the agreement now reached. Thank you very much.
The last time there were similar demonstrations of opinion during a visit by a head of government or state, the President of this House intervened massively.
At that time, it was about a matter that was of great importance to him, namely the Lisbon Treaty.
When the duly elected president of a country speaks today and is massively interrupted and disrupted by the socialist side, the president does not intervene.
Do you know what this is?
This is not democracy, it is arbitrariness, and I call for appropriate measures to be taken.
Madam President. Children and politics: rarely do the interests of citizens and politicians diverge so widely.
The topic of children is of utmost importance to citizens across Europe.
For politicians, children's issues are a low priority, as we can once again observe here.

I am not aware of any country that has a dedicated ministry for children's affairs, and even within the Commission, there is no specific representative tasked with advocating for the interests of our youngest citizens.
In parliament, the topic of children is scattered across all committees.
Therefore, I would like to specifically commend the Commission at this point for addressing childcare facilities and the Barcelona targets today.
In our parliamentary working group on Equality of Childhood, we have found the following: Our children live in a highly complex world.
The future of a person who is a child here, now, and today is completely uncertain.
A child today can climb to the very top of the social ladder or fall right down to the bottom.
It can remain within its own cultural circle or seek a new one.
An individual may follow a similar life path to that of their parents or do exactly the opposite.
One can marry someone of the opposite sex or of the same sex.
All of this was completely different more than fifty years ago, when we launched the united Europe from its baptismal font.
The diversity that distinguishes us Europeans has become a determining factor in the lives of children.
The concept of diversity must therefore be integrated into the pedagogy of child educators and teachers.
This is currently still being taken into account far too little.
Europe's childcare facilities and schools are indeed breaking under the challenge of integration.
In integration matters, we need to press the reset button, back to the starting point.
Let's approach this topic once again completely without prejudice, according to the motto "Unity through Diversity."

Moreover, I ask all my fellow European Parliamentarians: Advocate not only for gender mainstreaming, but also fight for child mainstreaming, especially now in the time of the global financial crisis, because otherwise we will burden our children with immeasurable debt.
Thank you very much, Mr. President. I'll keep this brief.
I would like to express my sincere gratitude for the constructive debate contributions I have heard here.

I would like to convey just two messages in conclusion. Firstly, I would like to expressly thank the Commissioner for not speaking out against the concept of minimum requirements for the safety net in principle.
This proposal is neither a devil's concoction nor a bureaucratic monster.
It is a problem-solving tool that we should give a chance.
That's why I would like to make another plea for this at this point.
The second point I would like to make, and this is directed at my British friends, across all parties.
My dear British friends, I do understand Caroline, I do understand your problem.
I can understand that, for a certain period of time, a country might prioritize energy security over adherence to air pollutant limit values.
I have great understanding of this.
I would be the last person to not give Your Majesty additional time when it comes to building new coal-fired power plants.
We can talk about it.
The problem is, we did not do precisely that.
This conversation never took place over the past four months.
I would like to ask you, in this second reading, to keep an open mind here and say, "Let's discuss a compromise at this point."
for what I consider to be a completely irrational, unjustifiable resistance from a competition and environmental policy perspective, the fundamental opposition to giving up minimum standards.
I believe that this is the point at which we can reach a compromise, which I hope we will ultimately achieve in the second reading.
By the way, I do not share the view that we should not seek a compromise in a first reading.
This legislation is too complex for that.
I do not wish to conclude this legislative term as rapporteur and leave the next Parliament with legislation where the text under discussion is inconsistent, illogical, and contradictory.
Therefore, I kindly request your support for the compromises when we vote in an hour.
Dear colleagues, the crucial question surrounding all the economic stimulus packages being put together across Europe is, of course, who will ultimately receive the money?
Further blank checks will be issued to banks, even though rapid nationalization would ultimately be significantly cheaper for the taxpayer.
And should corporations and high-income earners be further relieved, even though they have already been fattened up for years across Europe through tax breaks?

The more money that is squandered on such purposes, the more predictable it becomes that such programs will fail, and the more likely it is that the European economy will sink further into a very dangerous downward spiral.

The years-long policy of privatization, deregulation, and liberalizationâ€”it is precisely this policy that has increasingly concentrated incomes in the top ten, and it was this policy that is responsible for the current crisis in which we find ourselves today.
Those who believe that they can overcome this crisis by continuing the very same policies with minor modifications have simply not understood anything at all.
The exact opposite is required.
Instead of buying up toxic assets from banks, tax funds should be used for the renovation of schools, hospitals, and for the ecological transformation of the European economy.

Whenever private companies receive public funds, there must be no taxpayer money without job guarantees and, above all, no taxpayer money without the acquisition of public property rights, so that the state and, in particular, the general public of citizens can also participate in future profits later on.
The very best economic stimulus program that could exist at present would be a radical redistribution of incomes and wealth from the top to the bottom.
The low-wage sector in Europe needs to be reduced, rather than continually promoted.
We need higher minimum wages, we need better social benefits in Europe.

And we need taxes that ensure that the millionaires and beneficiaries of the past financial market party now also bear the immense losses that have arisen, and not the vast majority of citizens who, after all, never benefited from the entire financial boom.
I believe that what is socially just is currently also the only economically rational policy.
And it is the only way to break the devastating crisis dynamics.
Mr. President. In early March, political prisoners Mikhail Khodorkovsky and Platon Lebedev were transferred from Chita in Siberia to Moscow to face new charges based on untenable accusations.
The first public hearing date was set for March thirty-first.
On the same day, the human rights consultations between the EU and Russia were scheduled to take place.
These important talks have now been postponed indefinitely by the Russian side.
Russia is thus demonstrating very clearly the low value it places on human rights.
The judiciary continues to be employed not only to deny justice but also to eliminate regime critics, and the EU is being duped thereby.
Mr. President. Thank you very much, Commissioner, dear colleagues. I am particularly grateful to Commissioner Verheugen for addressing the ban on animal testing once again.

because it reminds me that this is the third amendment to cosmetics legislation that I have had the privilege to work on, the sixth amendment, the seventh amendment, and now the amendment to a regulation.
We have indeed succeeded in banning animal testing.
We have succeeded, for example, in ensuring that consumers know how long a product is still usable by looking at a small can with a number inside that indicates how much longer it is valid.

I am also addressing this to some colleagues, particularly Ms. Reuthofer, who unfortunately could not be present at the beginning. Markings are never warning signs at any time. If a product is not safe, it may not be on the market, it may not be marketed.
Every product on this European market must be safe and free from harm.
But the labeling gives consumers the option to choose.
This is democracy, and this is your freedom of choice.
I believe that we have very good legislation.
I have attempted to make the process highly transparent.
I have attempted, as Ms. Kostet also mentioned, to bring together different opinions.

For my part, I am committed to creating legislation that is good for everyone: for consumers in the European Union, for the industry that has to work with this legislation, and ultimately for all those who will benefit from it.
To my colleague Schnellhardt, I say once again, the DEO affects everyone differently, but the claim that it keeps you sweat-free is still made.
Therefore, it is important that the statements regarding my eye wrinkle depth after a week in Strasbourg are also realistic and reliable.
Once again, I extend my gratitude to the Commissioner, both for the statements he has made and to my colleagues and my staff member, who did most of the work.
I thank you very much.

Madam President, Commissioner, esteemed colleagues. The report by Mr Van Nistelrooy concerning the Green Paper and the future shape of cohesion policy is certainly one of the most significant reports of the Steering Committee in recent years.
We agree with the fundamental concept of the Green Paper, which posits that territorial cohesion is concerned with the polycentric development of the EU.
to ensure overall and sustainable development of the sovereign territories with their diverse characteristics and peculiarities while preserving their richness.
It is correct that in the next planning period, a more comprehensive system of gradual assistance for transition regions crossing the threshold of seventy-five will be implemented.
a percentage of the gross domestic product must be set aside, so that these regions can be granted a distinct status, thereby achieving greater security in their development.
And in the report by colleague Kreh on obstacles to the uptake of the Structural Funds, the most significant shortcomings are rightly listed, which applicants face when submitting their applications.
in claiming Structural Funds, such as excessive administrative burden, too many complex regulations, slow and cumbersome centralized administration in the Member States.
Various recommendations are addressed to the Commission regarding effective measures to be taken in order to eliminate these obstacles.
I would like to single out and emphasize two such measures.

Firstly, currently, project managers are required to retain their project documentation for a period of ten years in order to have it available for inspections that may be conducted by the Commission.
For smaller projects in particular, this is an excessively bureaucratic effort.
Correct, that this is now to be reduced to a period of three years. Secondly, the evaluation criteria of the EU Commission for innovative projects are causing significant problems.
In the case of innovative projects, the same evaluation criteria should not be applied as for other projects.
It is simply necessary that something different happens here.

Madam President. When Europe allocates funds, and especially when Member States invest significant amounts of money to aid the automotive industry in its time of crisis, it should not solely focus on preserving the status quo and preventing layoffs. Rather, there are a multitude of other considerations at play.
The most important ones have been mentioned.
It is about helping people find employment, and they also need to secure this employment, preferably long-term.
To achieve this, it is necessary that we promote new technologies, innovation, and above all sustainability in the transport system more strongly than we have done so far.

Therefore, we should align all our actions with these objectives as well, so that we do not have to face the accusation in a few years that we should have thought about all this many years ago, otherwise we would not be in the next and new crisis.
Madam President. It would be kind of you to also grant me the additional half minute that my Green colleague, Ms. Breyer, has just been given.
The Commission had presented a good proposal for updating the regulation on novel foods.
Unfortunately, some amendments seek to supplement this proposal with requirements that are not in line with the objectives of the regulation or even aim to interfere with existing case law.
The obligation of food business operators to monitor novel foods with respect to animal health and welfare would simply overwhelm traders.
Once again, there is an attempt to undermine existing GMO laws, specifically the demand for special labeling of novel foods derived from animals fed with genetically modified feed.
We have just heard it.
In principle, anything that relates to GMO legislation should not be addressed in the Novel Food Regulation.
I say this even though I myself, for example, had proposed that corresponding new plant species be specifically excluded from the definition of novel foods.
But it cannot be that interested parties in this House misuse the Novel Food Regulation for election campaign purposes.
It is apparently also the case with amendments two and sixty and ninety, for which the Greens have requested a roll-call vote.
Who, esteemed colleagues, do you intend to put on trial with this?
My faction, too, has always advocated for the consumer's right to know what is contained in their food.
Why, then, should one not indicate a nano-origin in the declaration of ingredients?

And although Amendment 2 and 60 somewhat clumsily attempts to pre-empt my report on food labeling, I must tell you that I consider this labeling of novel foods to be entirely compatible with my report.

I therefore recommend that my faction approve the aforementioned motions, and I will include references to the part of the Novel Food Regulation that deals with labeling in my report on the Food Labeling Regulation.
This is possible because we have postponed the first reading on food labeling until the next legislative period, against the will of the Greens.
But now it is clear to everyone how advantageous this postponement was.
Cloning, in short, is animal cruelty.
We are against it.
Nevertheless, food products must be included in this regulation accordingly, as they would otherwise no longer function within the framework of the law.
Madam President. It is quite simple.
Those who do not wish for this man to preside over the solemn opening session of the European Parliament should support my motion to amend the rules of procedure. Thank you.

Madam President, esteemed Commissioner, dear colleagues. One thing must be made clear from the outset: The provision of food to those in need, especially during these economically challenging times, is not up for debate in the upcoming vote on the report by our colleague Sikerski.
Therefore, I would like to make it clear from the outset that it was not easy to find a common approach within our group.
Therefore, I respect each of my fellow group members' personal decisions to deviate from our planned course and not support the rejection of the report.
Why can I not agree to the result of the committee vote in this form?
There are a number of reasons for this, which have absolutely nothing, nothing at all, to do with aiding the needy in the European Union during these economically challenging times.

On the contrary, the amendments tabled by my colleague Nils Busk on behalf of the ALDE Group, which unfortunately were not deemed admissible, were intended to place the existing system on a future-proof footing.
For the existing system is an anachronism from the times of agricultural overproduction, which fortunately belongs to the past.

Thanks to the successful decoupling of direct payments, intervention stocks have steadily decreased in recent years, meaning that today, up to eighty-five percent of food products need to be purchased on the open market.
However, this fundamentally altered the character of the program and resulted in the loss of its agricultural policy dimension.
As we are now dealing with a social program, we must establish an appropriate legal basis for it.
Herewith, we share the assessment of the Council's Legal Service, which refers not to Article 7 and 30 of the TFEU concerning the Common Agricultural Policy, but rather to...
Article 308 as a legal basis for this is feasible, otherwise it would clearly constitute an infringement on the national competence of the Member States.
The only solution, given the inadmissibility of our amendments, can be a new draft by the European Commission.
It should continue to adhere to the principle of co-financing, as only on-site can the meaning and futility of such programs be satisfactorily assessed for the benefit of all.
Mr. President, esteemed ladies and gentlemen. Firstly, we too welcome the proposal from the European Commission and this Green Paper in principle.
There is a mass phenomenon, described by various preceding speakers, in which relatively minor damages occur among a large number of affected individuals.
For the individuals concerned, the harm is small, but when tallied up in total, it is significant.
A tool is required to tackle this problem.
In my opinion, it is also right that such things are being thought about.

I also very much welcome, to remain on the positive, the fact that the Directorate-General for Consumer Protection has placed a crucial emphasis in its Green Paper on the question of alternative dispute resolution mechanisms.

This is a significant difference from the White Paper of the Directorate-General for Competition, which was also discussed here in this house yesterday and which has completely ignored this possibility of out-of-court dispute resolution mechanisms so far.
I believe that the Directorate-General for Consumer Protection is further ahead in its Green Paper than its competition colleagues.
I would like to make two points very clear, which, in my opinion, are certainly to be understood as critical remarks.
The Parliament will, in a few minutes at noon, adopt my report on the White Paper of the Directorate-General for Competition.
We will, with an overwhelming majority in this House, demand of the European Commission that a horizontal approach be taken in addressing this issue.
It cannot be that in the end we have sectoral instruments, one for consumer protection, one for antitrust law, another for the capital market, and perhaps yet another for the environment.

Perhaps one more for social affairs, and they all contradict each other. They all interfere with the legal systems of the member states and ultimately lead to a legal policy mess that no practitioner can handle anymore.
We have had numerous such examples in the past.
I am only thinking of the debate on the Professional Qualifications Directive, which we subsequently consolidated into a single instrument, as this fragmentation was no longer feasible.
The Commission should not make the same mistake here.
It should promote the horizontal approach from the outset.
This is the clear position of the Parliament, which will become evident in a few months, in a few minutes, right here.

One final point. I also very much welcome the consensus we have reached that we do not want a lawsuit industry modeled on the American system, with annual revenues of 240 billion US dollars, from which only lawyers benefit in the end, and consumers gain nothing.
We strive for genuine rule of law in Europe and wish to uphold our traditional systems and understanding of law.
Dear colleagues, there are numerous ways to address the lasting consequences of the unexpected financial and economic crisis.

This revision package, this legislative measure as part of the European economic program, is designed as a good response, even if not entirely sufficient, but it is first and foremost a good response to this temporary, albeit exceptionally critical, situation.
This also serves, among other things, to promote greater simplification of the procedures and more flexibility in the application of existing regulations.
Provisions within the Structural Funds Regulation following a request, dear colleagues, that the European Parliament has repeatedly made in recent years.

It is also welcome, and I would like to emphasize this particularly, that through an amendment to Article seven regarding the eligibility of expenditures, the Member States and regions of the EU are to be enabled,
investing structural policy funds in energy efficiency and renewable energy in the residential building sector, and that these measures should not only be available to low-income households.

The relevant amendment therefore rightly deletes the line households with low incomes and instead introduces an upper limit of four percent of the total ERDF allocation for each Member State for such expenditure.
This is just one of many proposed improvements.
In short, once this comprehensive package is implemented, it will result in an acceleration of expenditures and thus provide additional liquidity for the implementation of necessary measures.
Guidelines from the Structural Funds, the ERDF, ESF, and Cohesion Fund, as well as a simplification of the regulations, enabling the rapid implementation of the programs.
an effective contribution, albeit an insufficient one to address the current crisis situation.
Madam President, esteemed colleagues. In principle, I welcome the European Ecolabel.
It is indeed time for us to make a new effort to further disseminate this Community eco-label.
I also believe it is correct that we continue to uphold voluntariness in the future.
The mark will only gain acceptance in the future if there are clear criteria and standards that require the acquisition of this mark.
Here I appeal to the EU Commission to develop reasonable, clear, understandable criteria.
The concept of incentive should be at the forefront.
It would be regrettable if the establishment of the environmental label were to fail due to bureaucratic hurdles.
Ultimately, success or failure is determined by the consumer, as it must find acceptance with them.

Even though I personally have a soft spot for the "Blue Angel" we have in Germany, it ultimately should not be a matter of taste. Instead, it is crucial that consumers can quickly grasp the special features of a product at a glance.
Added value for consumers is only created if member states abandon their respective national symbols and there is ultimately a uniform symbol at the European level.
A whirlwind of symbols confuses the consumer and does not inform them.
A symbol, a statement. We should work together on this.

Mr. President, Mr. Commissioner, dear colleagues. I believe that, during this legislative term, we have accomplished quite a lot together with regard to the discharge procedure for European institutions.
I regret, however, that it took so long, as we have now essentially addressed everything that became apparent with the resignation of the Commission in nineteen ninety-nine, that is, ten years ago.

This indicates that we still need to make some improvements in our working methods and procedures, and ensure that the necessary transparency is achieved more quickly when it comes to informing citizens about the use of their tax money.
I would like to express my particular gratitude to my colleague Mr. Kazaka, with whom I had the honor of working on the parliamentary discharge for the EPP Group.

I very much regret this, which is why I have quickly looked again to see that a colleague who expresses himself very intensely about various matters of the European Parliament in the press does not participate in the committee's deliberations, nor in the committee's votes, nor in the plenary debate here.
I want to make this very clear at this juncture, so that it is documented and preserved for posterity. We are fully aware that there were a number of issues here.
We were, and we are, and it was the members present here now who, over the past five years, have ensured that the necessary reforms were achieved at various levels in the interest of the members.
For this, a very heartfelt thank you to everyone. We have done what was necessary, and we ensured that everything was not just broadly reported in the media but also collaborated on.
Thank you for the serious collaboration.

Mr. President, dear colleagues. The AUDI reportâ€”my sincere thanks to the rapporteurâ€”truly moves us forward, as it contains innovative elements, such as naming and shaming, a milestone in budget control.
Specific criticism instead of blanket accusations.
That the socialist faction is now backpedaling and prefers to sweep the truth under the rug is a scandal and a disservice to our oversight responsibilities.
The credibility of Parliament is at stake, and I urge my colleagues not to allow this.
A word on our greatest concerns, Romania and Bulgaria.
The Commission's failure in preparing for the accessions is most palpable here.
We have lost a lot of money.

The Commission has long been observing and only froze funds in two thousand eight for Bulgaria, amounting to over one billion Euro, and for Romania, approximately one hundred and forty-two million Euro.
Freezing money is not a solution to the problems.
The cooperation and verification mechanism, for which the Commission President himself is responsible, is a paper tiger, and the progress reports do not deserve their name.
Here, the Audi Report proposes suggestions for how it could be done better.
The EU Commission misled the Parliament on these countries' readiness for accession, and in fact, the Expansion Commissioner should draw consequences from this.
We are concerned, however, with the management of future accessions, and for this reason, this topic remains on the agenda.
Our faction will grant the Commission discharge, but I personally will withhold discharge from the Commission for this reason.
Unfortunately, the Commission's reform zeal, which one could once again catch a glimpse of last year, has already faded once more.
Stagnation in fraud prevention, nothing on the topic of prevention, increased ethics not desired, etc.
The Commission, and in particular Commissioner Kallas, should be clear about one thing if the new Commission wants to secure the Parliament's support.
Mr. President. Yes, we have a problem with copyright and we have a problem with the remuneration of artists.
That is correct, and we must also take action and do something.
But when we take action, it is about truly responding to the challenges of the digital age and not saddling dead horses.
I will explain to you why I arrive at this word.
The proposal at hand essentially keeps only one promise, and that is the promise to promote the music industry.
When we come to consider what happens to the artists themselves and their income, and when we calculate this, we also arrive at
Such low average amounts that they by no means serve to sustain an artist's livelihood, allowing them to make something out of it.
Moreover, this money does not directly reach the artists.
and the fund is too small to achieve anything.
An artist with whom I discussed this told me that there is a redistribution taking place here, from the living to the dead.
I had to disagree. It is a redistribution from the artists to the producers, to the music industry, and only to the big ones at that.
In conclusion, Commissioner, this proposal is not suitable.
We must find better ones.
We need to create something like a flag rate, for instance.
Even the proposals you make regarding the "use it or lose it" clause remain theoretical law.
Let us please do something intelligent and thorough, as recommended and requested by the artists in our hearing in the Legal Affairs Committee.
Mr. President. I regret, along with the rapporteur Gilles Sabery, that the Commission has not pursued its original plan for an integrated action plan.
There are many good reasons why all stakeholders, from local communities to the European Union, are striving to improve urban traffic conditions.
We know that most people in Europe live in cities and that current traffic conditions are far from optimal.
Therefore, in principle, agreement with the plan and the report by Mr Savary, to develop corresponding integrated proposals from the Parliament's initiative.
I thank him for his commitment and also for the concrete proposals.
At the same time, however, I would like to make it unequivocally clear that what many fear or believe they have to fear will not come to pass.
No one wants to take away the right of municipalities, local and regional authorities to shape their transportation conditions.
We merely aim to contribute from the European side to ensure that reasonable joint rules are followed here, should a municipality, a city, or a regional unit deem it reasonable.
The principle of subsidiarity is not jeopardized.
What we aim to do here is to safeguard this principle.
It remains that we strive, in the interest of citizens, to ensure that when a citizen travels ten, twenty kilometers within Europe,
As Europe continues to drive, he encounters a traffic-calmed zone that he believes he knows from his home municipality, but finds completely different rules in place there.
No one wants to impose city tolls or other such regulations on any communities, but if they are indeed implemented here, they should be done so in a way that is clearly understandable to citizens.
For more than a hundred years, we have agreed on the significance of common procedures regarding traffic signs.
This should also be the case for this topic in the future.
Mr. President. We have been dealing with urban traffic in the EU for a long time now.
Why, indeed?

We are not at all competent in this matter. Competence was originally constructed due to the fact that approximately eighty percent of the population live in urban areas, and due to the climate debate, it was decided to take on this issue.
Well, fortunately, through our protest, we were able to reduce the European Commission's ambitions to an action plan for urban traffic.
I thank Commissioner Tajani for his insight.
"Subsidere" indeed means to support rather than to prescribe, but he, as an Italian, knows this better than I, a German with only a basic knowledge of Latin.
My primary concern is that our report, the report of the Parliament, emphasizes the strict adherence to the principles of subsidiarity and proportionality.
Legislative measures at the European level are inadmissible for urban traffic.
Supportive Measures: That is our task.
A collection of ideas and the promotion of the exchange of best practices is beneficial.
Not everyone needs to reinvent the wheel.
Our cities require tailored solutions, but these can only be developed by the local actors, for they are the ones who know what is necessary.
Municipalities must address highly diverse situations. They therefore require sufficient scope for action, also to maintain the vitality of inner-city trade.
This is important for the attractiveness of a city.
It is therefore important not to exclude motorized individual traffic, but rather to focus more on urban logistics.
I would therefore like to see research into the intra-urban distribution of fine dust particles promoted.
This relieves a city.
It is also important to take demographic change into account.
Our society is ultimately growing older and older.
Mobility needs and housing requirements are changing.
We need a local supply of goods for daily use to reduce traffic congestion, and this also presents a challenge for retail businesses.
Everything else would only demand green fields.
In conclusion, we do not need an observation center for urban traffic.
Such a position would cost a lot of money and generate a great deal of paperwork that would only be filed away in Brussels. Thank you.
Madam President. I fully support the Commission's aim to create a legal framework for the coordinated introduction and use of intelligent transport systems in road traffic.

My years-long personal struggle to ensure the standard implementation of eCall, the electronic emergency call system, underscores the urgency for me on an almost daily basis. Yet intelligent transportation systems can do so much more.
They contribute to environmental sustainability, increased efficiency, enhanced safety, and non-discriminatory competitiveness in road freight and passenger transport.

Moreover, they support multimodality, among other things, by developing interfaces to other modes of transport such as rail, inland waterways, and air traffic, where the integration of intelligent transport systems has already begun.
All this cannot be achieved by the member states alone, but only as a joint task.

Intelligent transport systems, based on binding basic standards and regulations for minimum quality across the EU, improve the environment for innovation and provide planning security, especially for small and medium-sized enterprises.
I particularly welcome the planned open vehicle-integrated platform for intelligent transportation system services.

The action plan finally includes a timeline for the introduction of individual systems:

a) for road traffic safety, such as ESP and eCall,

b) for continuity in traffic management, for example, information on
Toll fees or traffic management: Avoiding congestion? The use of real-time road, traffic, and travel data will not only benefit professional drivers but all road users.
The directive aims to establish detailed requirements for the coordinated, EU-wide mandatory introduction of intelligent transport systems and their application in the Member States.
It also ensures the handling of personal data.

However, beware: The introduction of intelligent transport systems incurs high costs, as infrastructures and vehicles must first be equipped with the necessary information and communication technologies.
We still know too little about the willingness and ability to pay of potential users.
Mr. President, dear colleagues. We wholeheartedly support assistance for people with rare diseases.
However, amendment fifteen is entirely ethically unacceptable.
There must never again be a debate in Europe about lives worth living and lives not worth living.
There must be no political or societal pressure on parents in Europe to consciously decide against having a child with a disability.
The selection of embryos would be a major ethical breach.
Therefore, this amendment must be rejected, and it is not sufficient to merely remove the word, which unfortunately does indeed correspond to fascist language usage, "schreichen."
but it would still be about the fact that there would be a selection of embryos.
And it would be unbearable if this amendment, which speaks of the selection of pre-embryos, were to become a stepping stone for a new ethics in Europe.
We must firmly oppose genetic discrimination.
Therefore, Amendment 15 must be rejected in its entirety. Otherwise, our faction would unfortunately also be compelled to speak out against this report, which is otherwise unfortunately positive.
Mr. President. For the first time since I have been a member of this House, I voted against the discharge of the Commission in the vote on the discharge. I would like to...
I would like to present my reasons. Fundamentally, this concerns the manner in which the European Commission has handled and managed the accessions of the two new countries, Romania and Bulgaria.
We are faced with a multitude of problems in Romania and Bulgaria, including a high level of corruption and a significant amount of European funds that have gone missing.
The European Commission only began freezing these funds in the year two thousand eight.
We lost a great deal of money in 2007 and are now dealing with barely existent control systems or systems that function only intermittently.
In Romania, we are faced with a high rate of corruption and issues within the justice system.
All this is attributable to the pre-accession process.

My goal is to set an example and signal to the European Commission that it needs to adopt a different approach for future accessions. I also want to convey to the Commission that, based on observations in other countries, it could potentially achieve greater success if it wishes to do so.
I would like to call on the Commission to help the two countries build financial control systems that are worthy of the name and to eliminate systemic weaknesses in these two countries.
Otherwise, we will have a permanent problem and a constant source of concern for all of Europe on our hands.

Madam President, I would like to draw your attention to the fact that behind me, in the area where the far-right extremists are seated, there are individuals who are not members of parliament, and as far as I can see, they are also actively using the voting cards.

Madam President, Commissioner, ladies and gentlemen,

I expressly welcome Horst Schnellhardt's draft report and thank him for his excellent work.
In the wake of the numerous crises in recent years involving products of animal origin, which pose a risk to the health of both humans and animals, comprehensive legal regulation is indispensable.
A revision of the current regulations has become necessary.
We must continue to ensure a high level of security.
Although we fundamentally agree with the report, I see several points that give me cause for reflection.
The regulation was made less stringent in many points, thereby somewhat relaxing the trade in animal by-products.
Some examples There is a permission to use certain materials of category one in pet food.
Materials categorized as level two or three, regardless of their risk, can be disposed of more easily under official supervision when the waste volume per week is low.
The risk of animal by-products of any category is, however, determined by quantity only to a certain extent.
It remains the case that the European Commission will adopt the implementing regulation, and the draft, like its predecessor, contains numerous authorizations for the Commission.

In other words, the Commission can adopt comprehensive and fundamental regulations on the handling of animal by-products through the comitology procedure. This means that, unfortunately as is often the case, the Parliament is excluded. Thank you.

Mr. President, esteemed Commissioner, ladies and gentlemen,

Afghanistan has endured a challenging history.
I believe that families in these communities are particularly close-knit and that women play a significant role within the family structure.
Therefore, the economic development is of particular importance. Specifically, supporting small and medium-sized enterprises should be promoted to a very high degree.
And, of course, a modern infrastructure is also necessary to help the country develop more effectively.

I believe that infrastructure projects, in particular, could help to foster a greater understanding among people in these regions and, of course, through the use of information and communication technology, a different worldview could gradually take hold there while fully preserving their identity.

Ocean pollution only seems to capture the public's attention when there is another dramatic incident, and then there is intense discussion about the threat these persistent pollutants pose to our seas.
But unfortunately, this then often moves very far into the background in the meantime.
The persistent and repeated violations, which contribute just as much and dramatically to the threat not only to our seas but also to our coasts, must be taken seriously by us.
I would like to express my gratitude to my colleagues, with whom we were able to discuss this matter, for consistently maintaining the position that it is our duty to protect our sea.
I speak here as a citizen of a landlocked country, yet I feel a responsibility as a European to protect our seas from persistent pollution driven by cheap economic motives.
It is urgently necessary to protect interest and integrate the principles of the second maritime package, the third maritime package, as the Legal Affairs Committee has also proposed.

Madam President, colleagues,

I, too, would like to congratulate the rapporteur, Obiol Sidjama, on his excellent report.
Around the world, the situation regarding respect for human rights is very dire in many countries.
But also here in Europe, when we think for example of Belarus.
Therefore, the European Union must significantly intensify its efforts by implementing human rights policy across all areas and setting clear standards.
In our understanding, human rights are indivisible.
This can be achieved, for example, during negotiations for a new agreement with Russia through a binding human rights clause that permeates all areas of negotiation.
Furthermore, I would like to once again advocate for the Sub-Committee on Human Rights to be upgraded to a Main Committee.
The EPP-ED Group calls on the Chinese government and the Communist Party of China to engage in the upcoming human rights dialogue in a constructive manner.
This would significantly ease the relationship between the EU and China.
We have a genuine interest in improving bilateral relations.
But this dialogue must also be conducted honestly.
We will have to maintain our legitimate demands on China.
In our view, the civil rights activist must be released immediately.
The conversations with the Dalai Lama, the religious leader of Tibet, are to be resumed.
And so, the Chinese region of Tibet must be immediately accessible to journalists and UN human rights experts.
In my view, the People's Republic of China demonstrated ahead of the Olympic Games that it can grant more press freedom, for instance, without jeopardizing the country's stability.
Now she should have the courage to embark on new reformsâ€”reforms concerning re-education camps, the rights of the accused, the death penalty, religious freedom, and freedom of assembly.
These human rights she should genuinely address and engage in dialogue with us.
Madam President. We welcome with great joy and offer our heartfelt congratulations on today's decision by the Czech Senate,
President Klaus reacted, among other things, by claiming that the Lisbon Treaty was still dead, as it had been rejected by the referendum in Ireland.
With this, he rides as a political zombie into an attack on majority decisions of his own parliament and senate, confirming his disreputable and sectarian stance in other areas of politics as well.
Fortunately, after the positive votes, he only makes a fool of himself.
We Greens approach the European integration process with a positive and constructive attitude, of course, also with critical comments where necessary.
Once again, heartfelt thanks to the Czech Senate, Parliament, and the government.
Mr. President-in-Office of the Council, ladies and gentlemen. Last week, to my delight as a new member, we heard from Mr. Mahmalbaf in the Foreign Affairs Committee.

an Iranian film director who clearly told us that there were twenty democracies in Iran before this election, after this election, which he considered a coup, there is no democracy whatsoever anymore.

I, too, endorse this description. It was indeed an election coup, carried out with massive electoral fraud, which deprived the majority of the Iranian population, who had spoken out in favor of change, of their right.
Mr. President-in-Office of the Council, what interests me above all is this: There will be an inauguration in mid-August for the so-called reelected Mr. Ahmadinejad.
What is currently being discussed in the Council and also with the Member States?
Will there be an official, formal representation of the European Union and also of the member states here?
I hope there will not be any, because after this election coup, there should be no official representation of the European Union or its member states either.
Member states, as much as I advocate for further dialogue, however, no one is officially expected to represent the European Union at this inauguration.
What is your position on this?
How is this currently being handled? Thank you.
Mr. Giegold, one minute. The crisis in Europe was not solely brought about by unethical behavior in the financial markets, Mr. Barroso.
There is the growing social inequality, there are the dangerous and unsolidary macroeconomic imbalances between the member states, and there is Europe's dependence on rising resource prices.

The citizens of Europe deserve a Commission that consistently brings these deeper causes to the forefront of discussion, rather than taboos them, rather than does the opposite, rather than shifting the responsibility onto the Member States.
We need a genuine European coordination of economic and fiscal policy.
We need fiscal cooperation in Europe that puts an end to tax dumping.
Only then will it be possible to halt social division and finance the necessary ecological investments.
We need a policy that consistently promotes green technologies and lifestyles to such an extent that the EU's dependence on finite resources declines sharply.
This is an ecological green revolution. I do not find all of this in your program, Mr. Barroso.
This is the reason why I cannot vote for you.
We need a revolution of democracy. Mr. Barroso, imagine that you are a great person.
If you were to stand for election in Europe, alone, with no other candidate, how many votes would you receive?
What would the citizens do?
They likely would have listened to you today and seen that you promised everyone everything.
You would hopefully also receive information about what you did five years ago.
You have promised the majority a great deal, indeed.
One must compare what they have promised before, what they are promising now, and what is to be expected.
I think that is very little.
They stand for the old, for the failed Europe, for contributing to the financial crisis, because the Commission has failed, due to a lack of commitment on climate issues, and so on and so forth.
I would side with the majority of European citizens, as I believe they would not receive more than ten, twelve, or fifteen of the votes.
I would like to speak in favor of maintaining the new proposal, as it is clear that the negotiations in Honduras have failed.
There is no consensus proposal for this election.
This election is illegitimate because the current president came to power through a coup.
In other words, I am requesting that the plenary grant its approval for the proposal by the Presidency for this amendment, specifically the removal of the elections.
Democracy needs a revolution, and it is never wrong, colleague Dartmouth, to speak out in favor of transparency, colleague Verhofstadt.
And precisely you, during the Swedish Presidency of the Council, could set a shining example and really tell us how it will have gone.
There is concern over the highly unworthy horse-trading for top positions in the European project, and Mr. Barroso could take the lead in appointing the Commissioners.
Germany and Austria provide a negative example here, but unfortunately others do as well.
Qualified individuals are sitting in this hall but do not have the opportunity to gain access.

Please be brave now that the Lisbon Treaty has been adopted, and be honest and say that we need much clearer decision-making structures, transparent decision-making structures for commissions and top positions.
It should be possible to identify the right experts here in the European Parliament, instead of having to rely on individual federal states to build up their own expertise.
Mr. President. The topic we are discussing this evening has been on the agenda of the European Parliament on several occasions.
As is well-known, the Commission bases the granting of aid on the conditions of the International Monetary Fund.
That has been hinted at a few times already.
Against this backdrop, there have been repeated inquiries from the EP to the Commission.

In November two thousand eight, the EP called on the Commission to present an analysis of the impact of the behavior of banks that had transferred their assets from the member states that had recently joined the Union at the time.
On the twenty-fourth of April this year, the EP reiterated this demand.

Furthermore, the EP has demanded to be informed about the letters of intent that are concluded in detail between the Commission and the member states receiving aid, setting out the conditions for the aid in detail.
To the best of my knowledge, these requests have not been answered to this day.
My first question, therefore, is whether it is true that these inquiries have not yet been answered?
If that is the case, then my second question is: Why have these requests not been answered so far?
My third question is: When can we expect a response to these requests?
Ladies and gentlemen, the GUE/NGL will not support this resolution.
The Stockholm Program completely sails past the real challenges of the present.
The fundamental flaw is that a Europe of rights is being established, which is to be granted to EU citizens but not to other people living in Europe.
The same civil and human rights should not be granted to them.
On the one hand, the EU seeks to accede to the Charter of Fundamental Rights, which we welcome, but on the other hand, migrants are sorted according to the principle of legal or illegal.
Thus, Frontex is being heavily armed to combat so-called illegal migration, and I tell you, this completely obscures the view of an unbiased immigration policy.
Here Stockholm fails.
Another problem is the completely unbalanced ratio between security and freedom.
Yes, there is no freedom without security, but there is also no security without freedom. Freedom is not a bargaining chip, but a universal human right of every individual.

Stockholm, on the other hand, symbolizes the EU's obsession with security, as vast supranational databases are created without sufficient oversight mechanisms, consolidating intelligence and police data across Europe.
This makes the right to informational self-determination of individuals, mere waste paper, and the vision of a transparent human being an actual reality.
Allow me to conclude by stating, as an East German representative, that it is unbearable for me, twenty years after the fall of the Berlin Wall, to witness Europe becoming increasingly fortified.
Mr. Chair, Commissioner, you are correct. The rail system is a highly safe mode of transport in comparison to others.

While liberalization has brought many positive aspects, it has also introduced significant uncertainties through the fragmentation of individual societies, the separation of infrastructure and operations, the outsourcing of maintenance work, and the leasing of materials and personnel.
In my view, it must be ensured that national security authorities issue security certificates and approvals in accordance with the regulations of the ERA, the Railway Agency.
Are there sufficient controls in place?
is ensured, for example, that staff training, certifications, and working conditions are properly monitored.
What is the status in this context regarding the introduction of a uniform community certificate?
What is the status of the European train driver's license?
Efforts regarding ERTMS must be further intensified.
The recently created implementation plan, which you have outlined, must be binding and may not be delayed due to financial or national government considerations.
Efforts regarding the implementation of the technical specifications (TSI) must be continued and expanded.
This would be a significant advancement, especially in the homologation of the material, and would provide a higher level of safety in its maintenance.
Many of the recent railway accidents and near-misses can be attributed to inadequate maintenance.
Due to cost considerations. Particularly, intensity is neglected and the intervals between maintenance tasks are extended due to cost considerations.
What is the status here regarding a Europe-wide certification system for maintenance workshops?
In my view, everything must be done to prevent each individual member state from returning to its old rules and acting differently and autonomously once again.
In particular, border crossings between the individual member states pose a security risk.
How does the Commission intend to address this problem in the short term?
And in the balance sheet you are drawing up, I would like you to ensure that you also take into account the social aspects. Thank you.
We need a revolution of democracy. Mr. President, Mr. Commissioner, good morning in this new world of the Lisbon Treaty. This is an opportunity for you.
For eleven years now, I have been following your reports in this house, first as a journalist, and ultimately, they are very similar.
Now, however, you have the opportunity to look ahead.

Utilize the expertise of this house, which is not entirely coincidental, as many of the experts are gathered here in the hall right now. I see colleagues like SÃ¶ndergaard, Chaci Makakis, Staas, and from our list, my fellow campaigner Ehrenhauser. It is essential to rebuild the work of the Court of Auditors.
Look at what works elsewhere in Germany, where the economic viability and meaningfulness of expenditures can be examined, in Austria, and develop a plan.
Do you have a concept, perhaps as part of an initiative report that will come before the parliament, on how your work can be significantly improved to enable you to actually fulfill your tasks?
We need a revolution of democracy.
I vividly recall that the debates we are hearing today already began in this House ten years ago.
I would strongly urge you, Commissioner, to take particular note of what Arlem Desir, but also the Greens and some left-wing MEPs, are saying.

Don't you realize that with the approach the European Union has taken into these negotiations, we cannot rectify the imbalance as honest brokers? I believe, in light of what we are currently experiencing in these hours and days in Copenhagen, that we actually need a new approach.

Madam President, ladies and gentlemen. A microfinance instrument for the unemployed, those at risk of unemployment, and especially for people who do not have access to regular credit markets, is a good intention and is supported in principle by our group.
However, the performance demonstrated by the Commission and the Council in this process thus far is quite simply inadequate, partly incorrect, and cannot be supported by our group.
The first point of criticism concerns the issue of financial resources.
What is on the table in terms of financial resources is not a financial package for a program to combat unemployment; it cannot be referred to as a microfinance program, at best it is nano-finance.
Secondly, we are fundamentally opposed to engaging in such sleight-of-hand tricks that have no effect, are detrimental to other programs, and thus fizzle out endlessly.
Thirdly, the concept of sustainability and success of such a program must also include organic mentoring and coaching.
Many new startups, particularly in the microfinance sector, fail, which is why provision must also be made within the program.
Fourthly, it must be ensured that social security benefits in the member states are not withdrawn due to participation in this program, otherwise it will be ineffective.
This approach cannot effectively tackle unemployment in a sustainable manner.
We will reject it in this form.
