Colleagues,

In the transatlantic dialogue, there are many things that unite us, namely fundamental values and basic rights of freedom and democracy. However, there are also several aspects that divide us, specifically the application and concretization of these respective rights when it comes to transatlantic relations.
Above all, when it comes to questions of safety, this contradiction repeatedly becomes very apparent.
Data protection has long been a source of constant misunderstandings.
Therefore, if we succeed in obtaining a very good framework agreement, it will be a major step forward.
We must find a solution here that enables citizens on both sides of the Atlantic to assert their rights with the respective partner.
A second important point where we have similar fundamentals but vastly different approaches is climate protection.
Therefore, I strongly desire for this to become a topic of discussion and for it to be addressed clearly.
The European Union must not use the transatlantic dialogue to weaken its own promises and commitments.
For investment fund managers, there is now a certain degree of transparency and regulation in this opaque jungle of hedge funds and alternative investment funds.
Unfortunately, these rules have remained incomplete.
It is still possible to access the common market with unregulated products through passive distribution.
In essence, market access for these products is not effectively restricted.
Europe has thus missed an opportunity to extend its rules internationally and achieve uniform regulation.
Secondly, unfortunately, unlike what the Parliament desired, there was no effective debt brake at the European level for the funds.
It remains the case that national rules alone determine the extent to which fund debt is permissible, which means that the consequences of the crisis are not being drawn at this point.
There will be a national downward spiral in regulation.
What is crucial for us once again is that the plundering of companies by private equity funds is not effectively prevented.
Of course, there are private equity investments that make sense for companies.
But the rules now in place are, unfortunately, by no means sufficient.
Neither the information rights of employees, who rightly expect them, nor the protection of small and medium-sized enterprises from this form of plunder are effectively enforced.
Therefore, it is very difficult to justify this to the voters in this case.
Unfortunately, the responsibility for this does not lie with the Parliament; it lies in particular with intensive lobbying by the relevant industry, successful above all in the British context.

Government, specifically the French government, but I must unfortunately say also partly the German government, and here in the parliament we had a representation of these lobbies, rather in the form of the liberal faction.
We cannot agree to this proposal, as it would set a precedent for the Parliament's failure to enforce effective rules.
It is not possible for us to stand before our voters with our heads held high and say that we have succeeded in effectively regulating this shadow realm.
We hope to make progress on revising the policy then.
Many thanks once again, especially for the collaboration here with my colleagues in Parliament.
Yes, thank you very much. First of all, I would like to extend my sincere thanks to colleague Balz for his collaboration.
I can only emphasize this: even with differing perspectives, it has been a good collaboration.
Many believed, as I would like to emphasize once again here, that the crisis of the Eurozone was over.
Your country demonstrates that this has not been the case.
Europe continues to voluntarily submit to the financial markets.
The member states of the EU must continue to peddle their government bonds on the bazaar of financial markets and gain the trust of speculators through self-destructive austerity measures.
Over the weekend, we had to observe again where this is leading.

This time, it was not the allegedly fraud-prone Greeks, but model student Ireland, that was driven into the European rescue fund to save its banking system, which had also long been considered exemplary, indeed exemplarily deregulated.
Meanwhile, the financial sector is already eyeing Portugal's capitalization, with its interest rates continuing to rise.
The ECB bears a share of the responsibility for this drama.
She has failed and continues to fail to offer a civilized alternative to the state casino through the issuance of Eurobonds.
While one half of Europe recovers from the crisis, the ECB calmly watches as the other half sinks deeper into poverty and insecurity.
The systematic undermining of entire national economies might be to the taste of European funds and bank crises, but it benefits neither Ireland nor the currency union nor the ECB.
Mr. Trichet, do not heed Mrs. Merkel's simplistic financial approach.
Secondly, if you want to save the Economic and Monetary Union, do not leave European government bonds hanging in the air.
Introduce Euro Bonds before the next victim of speculation falls.

Mr. President, ladies and gentlemen, Commissioner. Considering how we debated this Commission proposal during the last parliamentary term, from total rejection to jubilation over all the wonderful things coming our way, I must say I am enthusiastic about what we have before us now.
And for this, the rapporteur and his fellow rapporteurs are greatly commended for synthesizing a coherent opinion from this wide range of perspectives.
I believe the magic word lies in the focus on the patient.
One did not, therefore, consider the many side effects, but rather asked: What does the patient need?
I believe it is correct that we have decided that the patient can inform themselves through various channels and not just one.
However, I would like to emphasize that the doctor will still need to be the patient's trusted advisor and will undoubtedly have an influence on crucial decisions.
We guarantee this because we have banned advertising for it, and the information the patient receives has been checked and approved by a regulatory authority.
This initially scientifically substantiates the information, and the patient can thus also safely handle it.
Of course, it is correct that not everyone can take on this investigation now.
About the internet. We have various methods for that, and I believe it is so widely used that we don't need to worry.
I only hope that the Council now finally has the courage to tackle this issue.
It is very important, action must be taken quickly.
Patients expect that.
And I believe then we have accomplished a great deed. Thank you very much.
Madam President, Commissioner, dear colleagues, coal is an undisputed part of energy supply.
It is also undisputed that competitiveness must be ensured and that subsidization cannot be the right approach.
The question now arises as to whether the date with two fourteen or two eighteen is the correct one.
Colleague Rabke has presented a wealth of insightful arguments that I need not reiterate.
My request to the Commission is essentially this: there is clearly a large majority in all the committees of the Parliament involved in favor of affirming that competitiveness must be a criterion.

But that in the question of the deadline, the necessary flexibility is simply created, which is certain to also provide the opportunity for Member States to implement it and to ensure that the burdens on people, jobs, and economic structures remain manageable.

The only argument that was mentioned, which, incidentally, was also in contrast to the Commission's impact, which also initially seems to advocate for two eighteen, was the argument that climate policy reasons could play a role here.
I want to emphasize this aspect again: It makes no difference for the issue of climate whether one burns foreign coal or one's own coal.

My request to the Commissioner is to consider whether this four-year deadline, when such new arguments arise in the Parliament and the Council, might not enable the Commission to show some flexibility as well.
I understood the hint to mean that the Commission is giving this matter thought, and I would like to express my gratitude for that.

Mr. President, Madam Minister, Madam Commissioner. If there is one lesson to be learned from Copenhagen, where you, Madam Commissioner, indeed held the presidency, it is that the European Union must speak with one voice at such conferences in the future.
We may differ in our opinions on this point or that, but if we Europeans speak with different voices there, our influence will not be credible, and if we are not credible, others will not follow us.
Why should you, either?
Therefore, it is correct that the figures we decided upon in the year two thousand and two under Chancellor Merkel essentially need to remain in place and form the basis of these negotiations.
I share your view that the ambitious two-degree target should not be significantly lowered today, as this would make achieving these goals exceptionally difficult and alienate people.
I have a great concern that we are calling our intellectual property into question.
So our industry invests money and manpower to develop things.
If we now go and loosen the fence around this intellectual property and leave the holes as they are at the moment, then our valuable assets, namely our property, will walk away.
I am very much in favor of technology transfer, but our companies must also see a benefit in investing in it, and therefore intellectual property must not be diluted.
As far as obligations are concerned, I also tend to demand serious commitments from our partners worldwide.
But they must be credible, and they must be feasible for these countries.
otherwise we will do exactly the opposite of what we want, namely, you will distance yourself from us.
So performing credibly in Cancun is an important aspect.
The truly major decisions will be made later in Johannesburg, but in Cancun we should prepare the ground.
I am a farmer by profession.
If the field is not in order, then there will be nothing to harvest.
Let's focus on the good academic.
Mr. President. There was an incident during the debate on the European Council this morning that I do not wish to dwell on further, as I was the target of an insult.

I would like to say, however, that there are levels on which I cannot be offended and where I do not perceive it as an insult, because in order to offend me, one must possess a certain degree of sincerity.
I would like to express my heartfelt thanks for the countless displays of solidarity I have received here in this house since then.
I would like to express my sincere gratitude to all of you, dear colleagues from all factions.
I believe this is a sign of our shared, democratic, and pro-European conviction, which the overwhelming majority of this House holds.
For that, my sincere thanks.

Dear Commissioner, dear Minister, dear Mr Gosses, and dear colleagues and shadow rapporteurs. Firstly, I am pleased that we have now taken this step, that for the first time a sector of the European financial system will be placed under direct European supervision.
This is also a step towards a strong Europe in a single market, for strong control over a sector that contributed to the crisis.
I would like to make one comment on this, dear Mr. Barnier. Currently, the selection processes for the new authorities are underway, and the new authorities are only as good as their staff.

I can only hope that in the selection of personnel, it will truly be a matter of expertise, independence from the financial industry they are meant to regulate, and a clear commitment to public interests. I also hope that we will not see national quotas again in the selection process, which override these important criteria.
Moreover, much remains to be done in the area of rating agencies.

We still lack genuine transparency regarding the information used by rating agencies. There is far too much reliance on regulatory ratings within the financial sector and in regulations governing the financial industry.
We face severe conflicts of interest, there is clearly a market dominance by three major providers, and we have no liability for negligently produced ratings.
Therefore, Commissioner, I ask you, it is good that the consultation is now underway, and we are eager to see the results.
I believe that civil society in particular should participate in this consultation. But then it must also be about making a bold proposal.
I am already looking forward to your proposal.
Be as brave as before, and let us jointly create legislation next year that truly solves the problems that still exist in the ratings market in a European manner.
We owe that to the citizens.
Mr. President, Mr. Minister, Mr. Barnier, colleagues. The harm that rating agencies can cause has been demonstrated in the past few months since the beginning of this year.
There is therefore an urgent need for action.
Therefore, I also welcome the directive insofar as it would assign supervision and registration of rating agencies to ESMA.
I believe this is an important and positive step forward.
However, numerous good and constructive proposals were lost in the negotiations over the report.
I would like to note this again here.
The mandate of ESMA thus remains the only real and positive innovation.
The proposals for a public database to create ratings have been dropped, and there is also no mention of establishing a public rating agency.
Even the consistent and continuous review of created ratings by supervisory authorities has fallen by the wayside.
The Commission had further proposed promoting unsolicited ratings to overcome the disastrous issuer mandates for evaluating financial market products, but nothing came of that either.
I hope that these aspects will be taken into account in the upcoming reports on this subject, which Jean Paul Groset and you, Mr Barnier, have mentioned. Thank you.
Mr. Chair, Mr. Commissioner, dear colleagues. First of all, let me also express my gratitude to those who worked on this report, especially to my colleague, Mr. Benson.
I would like to draw attention to two perspectives and perhaps give you something to ponder.
We agree that energy efficiency, the prudent use of energy, is the simplest and most reasonable solution.
The question is, how do we achieve this goal?
And I would like to pose the question: What has actually been achieved by our repeatedly approaching people in Parliament with new and higher percentage figures?
Have we truly achieved more and made a greater impact?
Or why and at which points has energy been used more sparingly?
I am learning that the industry, which consumes a lot of energy, is becoming more energy-efficient because it saves money by doing so and because it is advantageous for them.

I am learning that people, when they know that this device consumes more or less energy, and when they can see that and decide for themselves what the benefit is, they will then make a decision accordingly.
Perhaps the correct method is not to work with percentages, but rather to proceed by offering incentives.
Second Question The Commissioner has just presented very compellingly and clearly how complicated it is to even describe the concept, "What is it actually?"
How differently does this occur in the member states?
The colleague has just pointed out that the member states are also in vastly different situations economically, geographically, and in every other respect.
Is it the right answer to work with a number, to work with a binding figure, or do we need to come up with something more?

I believe that in energy policy, we need to break away from the past debate, which thinks it can achieve something with simple figures, binding targets, and so-called silver bullet solutions. Because clearly, we have not achieved enough.
Perhaps we should try the other approach, one that is differentiated and offers diverse responses, taking into account different situations and sensitivities, but also achieving an impact.
It is the effects that matter, not our personal feelings.
The regulation being discussed today has long received little attention in all committees.
Now, at the end, when the result was presented, some people in this house woke up.
Unfortunately, some were unable to attend the debate. It would have been very interesting to hear their perspective as well.
As a former member of the Convention, the spirit of the Convention is still very fresh in my memory.
which has clearly demanded in many areas that the European Parliament must be given certain rights in order to have and maintain its credibility within the institutions and vis-Ã -vis the citizens.
In that sense, what the convent has set before us has not yet been granted.
These were extremely difficult negotiations, especially on the part of the Belgian Presidency vis-Ã -vis the Council, which made it possible to achieve some important progress.
I recall what colleague Lehne already mentioned, which was the issue of the constant possibility of verifying whether the Commission has exceeded its competencies.
Of course, there are some less than ideal arrangements, such as international trade agreements, but nevertheless, I can agree with the outcome.
I thank the Belgian Presidency.
She truly went above and beyond to ensure something was done, and our rapporteur, who negotiated with heart and mind.
In 2013, I would like to make the following statement on behalf of our group. This is a proposal that my colleague GÃ¶ran FÃ¤rm put forward on behalf of our group in the Budget Committee.
We did not reintroduce this amendment, but the Green Group did, with forty signatures from Green members.
We will abstain from voting on this motion.
I have also reached an understanding with my colleagues from the Green Party. We are in complete agreement on this matter.
Since we have fundamentally stated that we are not submitting any new amendments as a faction, we abstain.
I would like to expressly state that we support this point on financial transaction tax and hope that colleagues from the other side of the House will support us in the votes in the coming days.
It is important that we do not use national tax systems against the internal market.
This is particularly important in the case of cross-border services. Here, equal treatment is required.
We now have a negative example in Hungary, where retrospective price limits were employed for crisis management.
This is not acceptable, especially in the areas of financial insurance and trade, but also energy, which are severely impacted here.
I hope that this will not also be employed in the field of healthcare services in the future.
I would also like to ask President Orban to review these regulations, as they fundamentally violate the concept of the internal market.
It is important that the EU addresses the issues of migration and asylum law.
The Commission has submitted corresponding proposals.
Currently, there is no precise analysis available regarding the implementation of the existing legal regulations.
There are also hardly any mature calculations and analyses available for the new proposals.
I may state that the EPP unequivocally affirms the right to asylum and the right to protection for those in need of protection.
The examination of reality unfortunately also leads us to the problem that the right to asylum is claimed for completely different reasons or even deliberately abused.
The right to asylum and subsidiary protection is not an instrument for the general immigration to the twenty-seven member states.
We must also ensure that organized human traffickers are not given the opportunity to profit in the billions from the fate of humans by exploiting our asylum laws.
Asylum procedures must be conducted in a qualified and meticulous manner.
Persecuted individuals must have the guarantee of finding protection within the EU.
Therefore, the Commission has included corresponding obligations in the new drafts.
I consider many of these to be correct, such as interpreters, proper medical treatment, and taking into account special vulnerability.
However, I also want to mention points that I consider problematic.
Member state authorities are provided with far too few opportunities to prevent abuse.
The possibility of conducting accelerated proceedings and summary proceedings should be restricted to a reasonable extent.

If an applicant grossly neglects their cooperation obligations, there are hardly any sanction options available, quite the opposite in fact. If they go into illegal hiding, the Member State should no longer be able to conclude their procedure negatively. When they resurface, they should have an expanded range of procedural options at their disposal.
Even in cases of obvious lack of merit, an accelerated procedure should be possible after the second subsequent application.
This entails significant cost increases.
Even the free legal advice in the form of a lawyer currently represents, according to the Commission's draft formulation, a significant cost increase for the states.

I simply and urgently request that the Commission reconsider the consequences of its proposals in terms of practical reality, financial implications, and the challenges they pose for the administrations of the Member States.
We aim for a high standard, but it must also be achievable and, above all, it must not place excessively burdened member states before completely impossible tasks.
Mr. President, thank you very much for allowing me to take the floor briefly once again.
I have a great request of you, Commissioner FÃ¼hle.
I want to begin by stating that false assumptions lead to incorrect cost estimates.
We are currently not seeing a decrease in the number of asylum seekers, but rather a significant increase.
This is related to visa facilitation measures, for example with regard to Serbia and North Macedonia.
We are currently also witnessing a massive increase in the abuse of asylum law in an attempt to enter a country of the European Union.

When one proceeds from the false assumption that contesting the first instance proceedings in a more qualified form would save costs in subsequent instances, one automatically assumes that all Member States, so to speak, have a poor first instance procedure.
That, however, is not the case.
Raising standards across the board inevitably leads to increased costs as a consequence.
An increase in quality standards for all involved and also the complication of processes will, in practical reality, lead to higher costs. I am happy to discuss this.
Therefore, I once again kindly urge you to genuinely take into account the concerns of the countries, as the practical reports from the countries are partly available and will also be provided.
Mr. President, dear colleagues. This report attests to the Commission's successful competition policy.
It must not be forgotten, however, that unregulated competition can also contribute to rising unemployment and the widening gap between rich and poor.
Unrestricted competition still takes precedence over the social needs of the people in the European Union.
The credo of free markets cannot obscure the fact that they not only repeatedly fail, but are incapable of permanently establishing social justice.
A few proceedings related to distortion of competition and price-fixing simply do not solve this problem.
A fair and at the same time social internal market only functions with strong and just regulation.
More is urgently needed for that.
It is, for instance, unacceptable to increasingly submit public services to private economic competition.
The report sets out guidelines for the Commission's future competition policy.
Much stronger consumer protection, the exemption of public services from competition rules, and the control of cartelsâ€”all of this is urgently necessary.
Moreover, a contractual clause for secured social progress is necessary, which is at least on par with the competition rules in Europe.
It is a truly significant hour that we are commemorating the Holocaust of the Roma and Sinti for the first time in the European Parliament today.
Let me begin with the farewell letter written by a fourteen-year-old boy, Robert Reinhardt, in 1943, before his deportation from a German children's home to Auschwitz.
He wrote: "I have found my parents again."
We are en route to the concentration camp.
I have come to terms with my inner self to the extent that I can bear death.
I would like to express my gratitude once again for everything you have shown me.
Greetings to all, farewell until we meet again in heaven.
Your Robert.

Ladies and gentlemen, this boy did not return, like five hundred other Roma and Sinti. Although Roma and Sinti, together with Jews, were among the first victims of industrial mass murder, the full truth about it remains unspoken even today, sixty-six years later.
And the complicity of the majority society is often concealed as well.
We need the full truth about this chapter of history.
The Holocaust against the Roma and Sinti must be punished and recognized as a crime against humanity to ensure that this history does not repeat itself.
We must passionately combat the prejudices against these people.
We must put an end to racist harassment and violence, as occurred, for instance, in Hungary two years ago, and we must do so with civil courage.
Freedom, equality, and solidarity are not the privilege of a few, but the right of all, for human and civil rights are indivisible.
Dear esteemed ladies and gentlemen, colleagues. In my view, the focus now is on truly harnessing the potential of the law.
We harbor doubts as to whether these possibilities are truly being exhausted at an institutional level.
We observe deficiencies in the procedure. Until today, we as Parliament have not received the list of candidates in advance, but only the final result.
It would be straightforward for us to send these to the Executive Directors now.

We have a clear lack of gender equality in the appointment of positions, and due to certain incidents in the process, we doubt that the member states are truly filling these institutions in the European interest.
This, along with the further points in our letter, justifies raising a fundamental question.
But beyond that, of course, it is a matter of the suitability of individual persons, and each person must be assessed individually according to their competencies.
There we see two major problems.

During the hearings, we witnessed one of the candidates denying that it is a European institution, instead speaking of a network of supervisory authorities, and even refusing to correct this when asked to do so.
When asked if you are willing to transparently disclose all lobbying contacts with the financial industry, we did not receive clear statements.
We have sent a letter to all three candidates, and for us, the voting result depends on whether we receive clear and comprehensive answers to it.
Mr. President. We, as the Social Democratic faction, are submitting the same motion.
However, I would like to recommend to my colleague Mauro and the House that we formulate it a bit more precisely.
We are dealing with a rather enormous influx.

Italy, like every other Mediterranean country, is certainly overwhelmed and unable to tackle the current problem alone. And Italy will undoubtedly not be the only country facing this massive influx of refugees.
We can assume that Malta, Greece, and Spain will also be confronted with this problem in the foreseeable future.

Therefore, our request would be to formulate the title of the debate very precisely as follows: a statement by the Commission on immediate measures by the European Union to support Italy and other EU countries affected by the influx of refugees.
Madam President, Commissioner, dear colleagues. I expressly welcome the outcome of the conciliation procedure.

By implementing the regulation, it will be possible to achieve, firstly, a high level of protection in the field of road passenger transport that is comparable to the standard of other transport operators for all passengers, including those with restricted mobility.

achieves results for people, secondly ensures a high general level of consumer protection, and thirdly takes into account the particularities that this is a transport sector largely shaped by small and medium-sized enterprises.

This removes the extreme demands that would have made bus transport almost entirely impossible due to excessive requirements, as well as demands that would have excluded the majority of member states from the scope of the regulation entirely.
Public bus services, which are of general benefit to citizens, must also provide high-quality transportation for people with disabilities and those with reduced mobility.
You should have a right to assistance, and in the interest of social integration, this should be provided free of charge.
Madam President. I would like to congratulate everyone, especially my colleague Kancian, for his efforts in the difficult and lengthy process of brokering a compromise on this challenging file.
There were successes, which have already been listed, but there were also disappointments, such as the scope and other subtleties, which have already been illustrated.
With this compromise on bus traffic, we have covered passenger rights for all modes of transport.
The next necessary step is to create a common, coherent, and efficient framework program for all passenger rights.
Fair and clearly defined rights are of particular importance for the EU's credibility with European citizens.
To be credible, it is essential that the coherence of rights for the different modes of transport be respected.
It cannot be otherwise that fundamentally different criteria apply to the rights of air passengers than, for example, to train passengers.

Therefore, it is particularly important that, when developing a framework program, we do not resort to the lowest and weakest standards, but rather that we keep ambitious goals in mind for the benefit of all citizens.

Madam President, esteemed Mr. President, dear colleagues. We are in the midst of a major economic crisis; we have been discussing this for months, and all of that is true. However, we typically talk in headlines and then cheerfully continue making decisions here as if nothing had happened.
I believe it is because we in parliament, too, do not act concretely enough and honestly enough, but rather engage in headline politics.
What, then, truly drives growth and stability?
Are we ourselves contributing to handling finances more responsibly and wisely?
Do we truly critically examine whether we are making the right expenditures, or doesn't each one of us have a new idea every day about where we can spend more money?

If we do not have the strength to focus the financial resources on future projects, that is to say, conflict and debate and decision-making, then it makes no sense to talk about innovation and research without providing the means for it.
This is relatively dishonest.
And if we want to stimulate the economy, then we must also pursue policies that encourage economic growth and do not spend every waking moment considering how to disrupt industry or the economy.
We continue to cheerfully pass resolutions, constantly demanding new ones even today that disrupt the economy in its developments.
Does anyone believe that merely mentioning the example of binding energy efficiency targets contributes to driving forward the economy?
Do you truly believe that the decisions we have often made in relation to energy have stimulated the economy?
Or did you disturb?
I would like us to be a bit more honest about this and then make fewer decisions, but perhaps make the decisions that truly move us forward.
This is more arduous, laborious, and will also lead to disputes, but that is the essence of democracy.
Mr. President. Colleagues. The call for a financial transaction tax is not new. For several years now, opponents of globalization have been demanding such a tax.
Yet just five years ago, hardly anyone would have believed that it could be feasible in the foreseeable future.
But this week, it is on the agenda of the European Parliament along with a CO2 tax and Euro Bonds, and I think that is a good thing.
The financial instruments that Anni Podimata proposes in her report are ones that I can only welcome and support, and I believe we will also vote accordingly.
These are urgently needed instruments.
The consolidation of public budgets has so far focused solely on cutting expenditures.
Cutting public spending primarily affects employees, pensioners, and the poorâ€”in other words, those who depend on the welfare state.
The revenue side of the public sector has so far been completely overlooked.
She is the second lever that can be adjusted to consolidate public budgets.
Above all, however, the main causes of the public debt crisis can also be appropriately involved in the repayment of public debt through the revenue side.
To consolidate public finances, an increase in tax revenue is simply indispensable.

In fact, the high indebtedness of public budgets is primarily a result of the nationalization of private debts, namely the assumption of the debts of private banks and the financing of the consequences of the financial crisis by the public sector.
The responsibility for the debt crisis by no means rests solely with the states.
It is therefore not only obvious but also politically necessary to make the financial sector pay its fair share.
With the financial transaction tax, this sector would finally be involved in repaying public debt as the main cause of it.
This is an important political signal that this report sends, if it is adopted as presented.
However, we also consider Euro Bonds to be a meaningful and therefore necessary instrument.
They contribute more to reducing debt than all sanctions or more or less well-intentioned advice.

The complaints of some surplus countries that their interest burdens will increase due to Eurobonds are, however, unacceptable, as these surplus countries also simultaneously profit from their exports to the deficit countries.
This can then be criticized as a transfer union.
But anyone who wants a social Europe, anyone who wants the EU to remain united in the future, must at least agree in principle to a transfer union.
In conclusion, I would like to address the Commission and express my hope that they will now finally present the proposals for a financial transaction tax that have been requested for over a year.
Mr. President, the rescue packages were intended to protect EU member states from insolvency.
However, they are imposing brutal austerity measures on people while leaving the perpetrators unscathed. Moreover, the Commission is now also interfering in national wage policies.
Dear Sir, it is absurd and it brings tears to one's eyes to hear this formal argumentation here, that this was never meant to be social policy.
This position is completely unacceptable. Wage policy is not a matter for the EU; this policy of the Commission is in flagrant contradiction to the very idea of this European Union.
The European Union was never a project for a race to the bottom in terms of wage competition and social dumping.
There is talk of rigid wages that need to be reduced.
In other words, it means that wages should reflect market conditions.
Ladies and gentlemen, blind people are talking about color. Those who formulate such statements have absolutely no understanding of collective bargaining systems.
They interfere with collective bargaining autonomy and reduce the much-vaunted autonomy of the social partners and social dialogue to absurdity.

I want to make it clear: This Parliament is called upon to ensure the preservation of autonomous collective bargaining policy, to protect social dialogue, and to prevent the further erosion of social security.
We need measures against counterproductive austerity policies and punitive actions. Thank you.
Mr. Barroso, you are a clever man, but you did not answer my question.

Therefore, I am asking again: When Mr Oettinger says that we currently suspect that certain plants that are connected to the grid will not pass our stress tests, do I interpret this to mean that you are aware that these plants are so poorly secured that they will not withstand the criteria?
Why then do you not intervene already today?
In my view, this is a real danger.
Ms Gabriele Zimmer now has the floor. I would actually like to ask the two representatives of the Council and the Commission why they feel they need to approach this topic with hot air.

I believe it helps no one if it is not explicitly stated that, especially in preparation for the Istanbul Conference, the member states of the European Union and the European Union itself must take clear and concrete steps.
must finally fully honor its commitments to development aid and that it cannot be tolerated in any way for Member States to increasingly shirk this obligation.
It is unacceptable that one billion people still go hungry every day and that most of them live in LDCs, the poorest countries in the world.

It is unacceptable that a large portion of our development aid does not go towards promoting and establishing agricultural structures, but that this share has rapidly decreased in recent years, considering there is a billion hungry people.
And then to speak of it: We hope that the LDCs (Least Developed Countries) become more shock-resistant, I find that slowly becoming cynical.
I call on you to address the problems specifically and clearly, and to make concrete commitments to genuinely assist the LDCs.
In the context of the internal market, public procurement law and the award of public contracts are essential components.

Mr. Barnier, when you say that you also want to promote social integration in this context, then I must ask you: I have heard little about the protection of social rights, I have heard little about the protection of collective bargaining agreements.
This belongs to the basic rules that, as you say, you yourself do not want to call into question.

If one wishes to protect fundamental rules, it is necessary in future to ensure, when awarding public contracts, that elementary social standards are protected, that collective bargaining agreements are not undermined, and that wage dumping is prevented.
This belongs to a modernized public procurement law.
I explicitly state that fundamental social rights must no longer be subordinated to economic freedoms and free competition.
Either we want a social Europe, or we want a perpetual conflict with the people who are turning away from this Europe, where they do not see their vital interests protected.

Madam President, Commissioner Kruse,

Radio frequencies are a precious and limited resource that must be managed with care, foresight, and consideration for the broader societal implications.
Therefore, the Radio Spectrum Policy Program assumes a highly significant role.
Radio frequencies must be utilized efficiently, taking into account economic, social, and cultural aspects.
To achieve this, the technical capabilities must be utilized to the fullest extent across all frequency bands, in order to generate maximum efficiency.

The foundation of radio frequency policy must be the Telecoms Package adopted last year, as it also stipulated that EU and Member State radio frequency management must equally serve cultural, social, and economic interests.
This must be taken into account, especially when harmonizing frequency usage in the EU.
In this context, I would like to point out that the implementation of the digital dividend I is being carried out at very different speeds in the member states.
Further opening of the UAF band, especially below eight hundred megahertz, should therefore be considered only after taking into account the experiences gained in clearing this band.
Many technical and financial questions are still not definitively resolved.

The issue of interference and the question of cost compensation for cultural institutions and local authorities in the technical conversion process, for example in the field of wireless microphones, has not yet been satisfactorily resolved.
In the allocation of frequency bands, the differing interests must be responsibly balanced against each other.

The widespread provision of mobile broadband networks, on the one hand, is a fundamental requirement in the interest of European citizens. At the same time, however, further development in the field of public and private broadcasting as an important instrument for information and cultural diversity must also be taken into account.
We must ensure Europe's positioning in the field of digital information technology and cultural diversity through appropriate technical development.
Mr. President, dear Mr. Rehn. I would like to say first of all, as you have described, the situation has deteriorated.
The eurozone is experiencing a divergence between countries that are recovering and those that are faring weaker.
and the costs of supporting the weaker countries are rising ever higher.

In this situation, I have a few questions for you. As the Commissioner for Monetary Affairs, I ask you: In the course of two days, liabilities and claims between the central banks within the ECB system have piled up to over four hundred billion euros.
This is due to the fact that banks are still not adequately financed by the capital market.
How do you assess these liabilities not provided for in the Eurosystem?
Then the major problem, why we are not making progress with debt restructuring, is that the banking system, as Ms. Ford also stated, is not properly structured.
The proposal for a European restructuring system has been delayed.
When will the Commission present this?
And how do you, as the Commissioner for Economic and Monetary Affairs, assess this delay?
What do you do to make it go faster?
Then, as the Greens had predicted earlier, we saw that the measures taken against Greece and Portugal were ineffective as long as the macroeconomic conditions in the eurozone did not improve.
We still have absolutely rising interest rate burdens macroeconomically for these countries.
during increasing capital exports and capital flight in some of these countries
And we still have a lack of demand from several European partner countries, especially from the strong euro countries.
And we are seeing rising resource and food prices, at least if we discount the recent ups and downs.

I wonder, alongside the bailout for these countries, and the financial aid, what measures are being taken to provide macro-economic relief to the weaker nations on these fronts: taxes, external demand, and interest rates.
And you?
I would therefore encourage you to propose a strong package that macroeconomically improves the conditions of these countries in the Eurozone.

Lastly, in my opinion, the measures have affected the weakest in the countries of Greece, Portugal, and Spain, contrary to the spirit of the EU Treaty. Meanwhile, the stronger, the wealthy, have so far not been required to bear any part of the burden.
What measures are you taking to ensure that the wealthy are also included in contributing to the costs of this crisis?
Mr. President, Ms. Kinga GÃ¶nz is a member of my group.
One can be against Ferenc Joachani, one can be for Ferenc Joachani.
One can either reject Kinga GÃ¶nz as a politician or support her.
It is certainly free and independent for everyone to determine whether one is for or against a person's political belief.
The debate we are having here is about the last dictatorship in Europe.
And we are introducing them to one of the most brutal and bloodthirsty dictators on the European continent.
I find it absolutely unacceptable that a democratically elected member of my group is compared to a bloodthirsty dictator.

Madam Commissioner, esteemed colleagues, and dear visitors,

The cultural diversity of Europe is a valuable asset that we must preserve and continue to foster in the future.
To make this possible, we must face the challenges of the digital age not only in the information and knowledge society, but above all in the field of the cultural and creative sectors.
Cultural diversity is not only an ideal value but also a significant economic factor.
In the EU, approximately five million people are employed in the cultural sector.
This corresponds to approximately two and a half times the total employment.
The cultural sector is a growth sector that is developing faster than many areas of the rest of the economy.

The development of information and communication technologies is driven by the content provided by the cultural sector, just as the nature and quality of this content have been transformed and enhanced by technology.
We therefore need framework conditions for the culture and creative industries that enable them to develop sustainably in the face of the challenges of the digital age.
We need a modern, accessible, and legally secure system in which everyone can develop equally.
Culture and the creative industries are a driving force for Europe.
Therefore, we must also pay attention to this area in the context of school and vocational education.
We need to impart cultural and creative competencies to young people and also in the offerings of lifelong learning.
We must also better strengthen the entrepreneurial skills of cultural creators, and not just entrepreneurial competencies, but also good media literacy in the field of new technologies.
We need framework conditions that enable cultural creators to secure their livelihood.

Therefore, we will have to deal intensively with questions of copyright, social security, and intellectual property, but also with the open access to information and content, in order to further develop.
ensuring the creative and cultural industries' future in a digital environment and also preserving Europe's cultural diversity and cultural heritage as an essential feature of the European Union.

Mr. President, dear colleague Kellam, dear colleagues from the Baltic countries, dear colleagues. Today, we commemorate in a special way the expulsions and mass deportations from the Baltic countries.
These expulsions rank among the darkest events in European history.
Indeed, the past century was not inappropriately, and not least of all, dubbed a century of expulsions.
And we all bow our heads today in remembrance of the victims of these inhuman acts.
We demand a comprehensive elucidation of Soviet history and, in particular, the atrocities of Stalinism in this context.

And today's Russia should not perceive this as a political attack, but rather as support for coming to terms with its own history, which is characterized by periods of light and shadow, just like the history of other European countries.
But as we remember the victims from the Baltic countries, we also remember the Armenians who were driven out of Turkey at the beginning of the last century.
We commemorate the so-called population exchange between Turkey and Greece.
The deportations in Europe reached a particular peak in the middle of the century under the Nazi regime and the communist regime of the Soviet Union.
The expulsions after World War II also left deep wounds, as did the expulsions during the Yugoslav Wars.
We must also not forget that many colonial regimes were characterized by expulsions.
We must demand a serious confrontation with the various forms of expulsions and the bogus justifications.
And this also includes clarifying the guilt and punishing the guilty, insofar as this is still possible, as is now the case with Mladic, for example.

But the crucial answer lies in European unity, especially through and with the independent Baltic countries, and a clear commitment to continuing the European unification process, which is still ongoing.
This historic task is what we owe not only to ourselves, but above all to the victims of the many expulsions in Europe.
Many female politicians from all countries of Europe, both East and West, have worked on this.
Let's think, for example, of the Danzig Declaration signed by Polish President Wojciechowski and German Federal President Rau.
And because we want to learn from the past, we must remain vigilant, even towards the first signs of expulsions, such as in the case of the Roma.

We must reject all statements, such as the suggestion to send Arab immigrants back across the Mediterranean in boats, and we must resist those who seek to undo Europe's borderless achievements and bring back a new, narrow nationalism.
Let us bow in reverence to all the victims of expulsion and deportation, but let us unanimously affirm the continuation of European integration as the only true guarantee against a

The politics that brought so much misfortune upon the people of Europe, and indeed beyond, in the last century. Never forget, never again were demands that arose immediately after the Second World War.
They have not lost any of their validity; they are best preserved in a united Europe.

Madam President, Commissioner, esteemed ladies and gentlemen, dear colleagues. I had the opportunity, as a parliamentary election observer, to witness the referendum on the independence of South Sudan, and I was impressed by the overwhelming consent of the South Sudanese to determine the future of their country themselves.
I also witnessed the great expectations among the people, who viewed their country's independence as liberation from slavery.

Thousands, perhaps tens of thousands, of so-called internally displaced persons, driven from their homes by decades of conflict in the south and sheltered in refugee camps in the north, are now embarking on the journey back to their former homeland in South Sudan.

And of course, the people of South Sudan, alongside the independence of their country, above all wish to live in peace and embark on a path towards a happier future, after decades of armed conflict that has cost the lives of millions of South Sudanese.
On July ninth, the new state of South Sudan is set to become officially independent, thus enlarging the family of nations in our world.
The starting conditions are about as bad as they could be, and much has already been said about this here.
Seventy of the people live as normative cattle herders, eighty are illiterate. The conflict over Abyei is escalating into a military conflict.
There were already dead and wounded there.

As if that were not enough, rivalries between tribes and armed groups in South Sudan are also escalating, and according to estimates by observers, more than people have already lost their lives since January.
The wounded and violated are barely counted.
Sudan was already among the failed states.
There is a risk that the state of South Sudan is already starting out as a failed state.
I firmly believe that Europe has a great obligation to this region.
In light of the colonial past of these countries, the European Union's common foreign policy is called upon, together with the UN and the African Union, and it can also prove itself here.
It is not just about money, but also about supporting the fragile, emerging civil society.

And we must negotiate firmly with those who hold the fate of the country in their hands, namely the tribal leaders, heading the military groups, to ensure they do not dash the hopes of their people in the country. Thank you.

Madam President, Commissioner, colleagues. I am very grateful to my colleague Mr Bartolozzi for making Mongolia the subject of a debate in the European Parliament through his initiative on this question.
While the formerly Soviet states of Central Asia are now addressed from various perspectives in Parliament, Mongolia and its situation have only been sparingly reflected here.
It was indeed, quite unjustly, Mongolia that, as a state of the former communist bloc, made early use of its independence and embarked on a path towards the democratization of its society.

As early as 1992, the Mongols adopted a democratic constitution, and since then several elections have taken place, which, according to observers, have overall been democratic and conducted correctlyâ€”a fact that is by no means a given in the states of this region.

The Mongolian government has been attempting for several years to combat corruption through legislation and imposed a moratorium on the death penalty in two thousand ten, something that even some major democratic states have not achieved to date.
Nevertheless, the three million inhabitants of this vast country, dominated by extreme climatic conditions, are suffering from the consequences of an ongoing transformation process.
And so, a rural population that has hitherto lived predominantly as nomads is flooding into the few cities, which are not infrastructurally prepared for this.
The country's mineral resources are not being extracted in an environmentally friendly manner.
Energy problems are hindering civilian and economic life.
Trapped between the large neighbors Russia and China, Mongolia risks falling even more strongly into the dependency of these states than before.

The efforts and successes of Mongolia, and here I see the glass as half full rather than half empty, in democratizing its society should be acknowledged, as they are exemplary for this region and demonstrate what is possible despite a challenging past.
Mongolia should continue to receive our support, not only through aid programs but also through the direct presence of the European Union in the Mongolian capital with its own representation.

Representation as a sign that the fate of Mongolia is not indifferent to us Europeans and that European interests should not continue to be represented from the legation in Peking. One more sentence, please.

Madam President, on the intermediate category. Certainly, at the beginning, I could also have imagined other solutions, Mr. Pieper, after, for example, the regions that have so far received the maximum aid and will no longer receive it after 2013 are granted a transitional arrangement.

Mr. President, esteemed ladies and gentlemen, dear colleagues. Interregional cooperation will become increasingly significant in the future.

Cross-border concepts and projects in areas such as infrastructure, corporate cooperation, research collaboration, labor market development, and further training are driving forces for large parts of the European Union.

Madam President, esteemed Commissioner, dear colleagues. After nearly three years of intense work, after far more than three amendments, after countless conversations and discussions,

Debates. Following the most challenging technical negotiations and political trilogues, the political package, the major compromise between the European Parliament and the Council, on the future labeling of foodstuffs, is now ready for voting.
This regulation aims to provide consumers with more and better information about food, enabling them to make informed purchasing decisions.
But that is not all; the European food industry is also intended to benefit.
Legal certainty, deregulation, and better regulation are the goals.
This is particularly important for small and medium-sized enterprises (SMEs), and it is crucial to know that the food sector in the European Union is comprised of over eighty percent SMEs.
At the same time, this labeling must fit every food and non-alcoholic beverage, from staple foods to highly processed ready-to-eat meals.
Therefore, a mandatory labeling system using traffic light colors is not feasible, as this type of labeling simply does not apply to staple foods.

Despite all the difficulties, despite all the political and ideological differences in the Parliament, despite all the national egoisms of the member states, the compromise now achieved can certainly be seen as a success.
Allergens will be immediately recognizable at first glance.
The plant origin of vegetable oils is stated.
There is a country of origin labeling for pork, poultry, sheep, and goat meat.

For further products, an impact assessment will indicate whether and how the origin can be specified, for example, for milk and dairy products, or products consisting of a main ingredient such as meat in processed foods.
Products, etc. Imitations must be clearly marked on the front, and the same applies to formed meat and formed fish composed of, and glued together from, small pieces.
A package must not give the impression that it contains something that it does not.
If an image of fruit is on a yogurt, it must also contain fruit, not just coloring and flavorings.
In addition, there is the mandatory declaration of the most important nutrients always per hundred grams or hundred milliliters for reasons of comparability.
Added water in meat must be indicated, the date of the first freezing for meat and fish, and many more details.
The most important thing, however, is that all information must be legible.
We have defined readability, established a minimum font size, and mandated the Commission to set binding rules for further factors, such as the contrast between the text and the background.
At the same time, we protect craftsmanship from excessive costs and bureaucracy.
Unpackaged fresh products must provide allergen information but not the full nutritional information, which would require costly analyses.
The Commission initially wanted this, but it would have destroyed the national and regional peculiarities and specialties, leading to a European homogenization, and that is why we prevented it.
But now we have all agreed, and the reputable consumer protection organizations are quite satisfied with what has been achieved.

I would like to thank all those involved: the shadow rapporteurs, the Commission, and in particular Commissioner Dalli for his statements, which he will hopefully make shortly and which will untangle the knot that has formed in our political discourse.

Madam President, Commissioner, dear colleagues,

Given the current extraordinary situation resulting from the financial, economic, and budgetary crisis, decisions at the European level should focus on urgent and essential matters.
Only in this way can we restore the trust of our citizens in the seriousness of our actions.
My report addresses the strategy for preventing infinite human suffering, resulting from approximately thirty-five deaths and over one million cases annually.
five million often severe injuries resulting from road traffic accidents, as well as the prevention of an associated economic loss of one hundred and thirty billion euros annually.
The number of deaths alone corresponds to the number that would be mourned in the crash of two hundred fifty fully occupied medium-sized passenger aircraft.
What would we not do to prevent that?
The accident-related costs exceed the annual overall budget of the European Union by a significant margin.
Therefore, I am confident that it is beneficial for us to engage in sustainable activities in this field.

Thanks to the constructive cooperation of all shadow rapporteurs and many colleagues, we have succeeded for the first time with this report in developing a uniform, holistic, coherent approach to improving road traffic safety.

It takes into account the content of the UN Charter for Road Traffic Safety from 2010 to 2020 as well as the content and objectives of road safety work in the EU member states and broad sections of civil society.
It encompasses, firstly, ambitious yet realistic goals for the period up to two thousand twenty, and with Vision Zero for the time beyond that.
Thus, by 2020, the number of fatal accidents is to be reduced by fifty, the number of children killed by sixty, and the number of seriously injured by forty.
This is in the utmost interest of each and every one of our citizens, as well as in our national economy.
We recommend that member states adapt goals and methods to their own territories and expect them to develop their own road safety action programs.
Secondly, it encompasses who is responsible for the individual activities and measures.
This is by no means just the European Union.

In the spirit of subsidiarity, the holistic approach entails that Member States, regional or locally responsible enterprises, and indeed every individual road user, in accordance with their duty to cooperate, have a responsibility to act.
And it includes thirdly, how, with which instruments, activities, and measures the objectives are to be achieved.
Legislative proposals at the European level are just one strategy.
We cannot and do not wish to do without guidelines, recommendations, and commissions.
In this process, particular attention has been paid to subsidiarity, which means that competencies and responsibilities have been clearly defined, even where they are shared.
We appreciate the Commission's diverse activities.

Since they come from the most diverse general directorates such as transport, economy, consumer protection, environment, communication, research and development, internal market, and others, they are not always coherent, often uncoordinated, and sometimes even contradictory.
Therefore, we propose the appointment of a Road Safety Coordinator within the European Commission.
This effectively prevents the establishment of a road traffic safety agency, but greatly increases the efficiency of the European Commission.
Both the selection of measures and their evaluation require a scientifically grounded approach based on comparable, high-quality data, definitions, and statistics.
We therefore demand, among other things, a harmonized analysis of injury and accident causes, as well as the EU-wide exchange of data while maintaining a high level of personal data protection.
Six main areas of action have been identified.
They concern humans as participants in traffic, road traffic regulations, vehicles, infrastructures, their intelligent networking, as well as the particular consideration of vulnerable road users.
I request approval for tomorrow.

on the condition that industries in Europe, which would otherwise be disproportionately burdened, can be relieved, as they would not be able to compete with other regions of the world.

Mr. President. I would like to start by thanking the representative of the Council for the very clear description of the current situation.
In this debate, we have continually heard that it is about improving the situation for working women who are deciding to have a child.
In my view, the directive places too much emphasis on increasing maternity protection to twenty weeks.
But do we truly believe that the decision to have a child can be reduced to twenty weeks of maternity protection?

As the mother of three children, I am well aware that comprehensive concepts for offerings and good family-friendly options are essential to positively influence the decision to have children and to promote equal opportunities for women.
The present draft guidelines fall far short of addressing the diverse, partly very good service and overall concepts in some member states.
We need flexible solutions that address the situation in the member states and societies and the resulting needs of families.
Maximum demands and wishful thinking will not lead to a solution here.
Therefore, we first need to develop a solid and realistic basis for negotiations here in Parliament.
The comprehensive protection of mothers and the well-being of children are of the highest priority here.
This can be ensured in various ways with different models.
Those who want to bash their way through the wall with their heads don't necessarily reach their goal faster.
A lack of willingness to compromise does not open doors or build bridges.
A moderate proposal would be a better solution for enhancing maternal protection in order to make progress on this issue.

I believe that we truly need to revisit our approach, basing it on the Commission's draft directive but allowing for more flexibility to accommodate the different models in place in the individual member states. This will enable us to significantly enhance maternal protection for women and also the protection afforded to children in their early months of life.
This does not work with the draft that is presented here today, which certainly did not have the broad majority, as some colleagues tried to make clear today.

I would like to see a little more flexibility, a little more realism, and a better appreciation of what the member states have already achieved today, without calling our fundamental demands into question.
Madam President, Commissioner, I would like to make a few comments on the tax agreement between Germany and Switzerland, as others have already done.
Instead of putting a stop to tax evasion, which would be sensible, and closing loopholes for tax avoiders, what has been created here is a Swiss cheese with large holes.
The planned transition period of five months gives tax evaders ample time to transfer funds from Switzerland to other tax havens.
Since foundations and trusts are not covered by the agreement, it is sufficient to convert the assets parked in Switzerland into foundation assets.
Corresponding forms are available at Swiss banks.
Some time ago, the German tax authorities received information about several tax evaders who are hiding their assets in Switzerland.
The agreement now grants these individuals an amnesty, and tax authorities may no longer use the information at their disposal.
What kind of agreement is this that ties the tax negotiations down?
In a promotional video for Swiss banks, it is stated accordingly about this agreement: in the future, customers will benefit even more from the values of the Swiss financial center.

This agreement clearly lacks the necessary coordination at the EU level, and it also runs counter to the EU's efforts to increase transparency in tax matters, to make tax collection more efficient in the member states, and above all, to combat and prevent tax fraud.
Therefore, this cannot be acceptable from our perspective.
We call on the EU to also advocate against this in cases of doubt.

refrain from doing anything jointly, do not establish shared tools, do not set common indicators, use vague formulations wherever possible.

In light of the impending winter, it must not happen again that people end up on the streets, are evicted, and ultimately freeze to death due to rising energy prices.
Here we bear a shared responsibility, the responsibility as the European Union.
We must stand up for this, not for the nationalist ramblings we have heard from the right-wing side.

What would we have advised our colleagues, nineteen thirty-one or nineteen thirty-eight, when we were in the midst of a depression, as the financial markets had already undermined the democracies back then, and as we were heading towards war?
I believe two things are necessary as emergency measures: We need something akin to a transitional government.
Do what you must do quickly, don't let yourself be held back, regulate every product, every institution, and every player as if it were a woman.
Mrs. Merkel has said. But a transitional government alone, enforcing the financial policy emergency program, cannot have a future if there is no democratic policy emergency program.

In other words, in this case we clearly need a European community, we clearly need different treaties, and we clearly need a functioning instrument that only gains legitimacy when there are popular referendums.

And for this, we need to raise awareness now, as the situation has become so dramatic that there must be a complete change in thinking before the right-wing, before the national divisors, regain the upper hand over something that was actually already built.
Madam Chair. There is no doubt that this House stands for transparency and openness towards the citizen.
Of course, my EPP group also does this.
But the present report goes far beyond the actual objective.
Existing legislation and interinstitutional agreements are being ignored, with a disregard for the protection of competitive procedures, sensitive, and personal data.
This is a serious breach of data protection, for which we always advocate so strongly in other contexts.
Should we now sacrifice the privacy of the global public?
The present report poses precisely this risk, as administrative processes and decisions, including, for example, personnel matters, are to be published.
The same applies to the protection of trade secrets and sensitive information within the context of approval procedures, court proceedings, and competition law proceedings.

With its vague, unclear, and overly broad definitions, the report permits public access to such documents as well. For, as a document, it defines all data and content that are in any way related to the policies, measures, and decisions of all organs and institutions of the EU.
This includes, to a large extent, preparatory, confidential, and secret documents as well as all related information.
And thus, this definition encompasses not only documents but also information.
Information from ongoing interinstitutional procedures, such as informal trilogue negotiations, should also be published.
Do you know, Mr. Rapporteur, for indeed, what that means?

It means public access to the process, it means public influence on the decision-making procedure. We might as well invite the lobbyists to the table and let them negotiate. Is that what the citizen wants?
I cannot imagine it.
In addition, documents related to non-legislative procedures, measures of internal administrative bodies, etc., are also to be published. Where is the public interest in this?
or would it rather hinder our work?
I believe this report is not in line with the interests of our citizens.
It would trigger a flood of useless information.
He would render our work impossible, and above all, as you have heard from the Commissioner, he is unacceptable to the other institutions because he violates existing rules and laws.
You know that, Mr. Rapporteur, and in essence, you are thereby working against greater transparency and against the citizen.

Mr. President, Mr. Commissioner, esteemed colleagues,

When dealing with such an important and comprehensive topic as the White Paper on the future of transport, there is always a significant risk of ending up with a Christmas tree, where everyone tries to incorporate their two or three desired topics.
When one considers the result that will be put to the vote tomorrow, one can without doubt congratulate our rapporteur, Mathieu Grosch.

He managed to distill a good, coherent, and comprehensive result from several hundred proposed amendments, placing the main emphasis for the transport of the future on safety, environmental protection, energy, and technology.
I expressly welcome the fact that important issues such as the social, health, and labor law conditions of employees are also adequately addressed here.

This is particularly important in light of the looming shortage of skilled workers in the transportation sector, which must be actively addressed if future bottlenecks in highly qualified personnel are to be prevented.
Further opening of cabotage in road transport must be conditional on preventing social dumping and unfair conditions.
I also welcome the fact that the aspect of improving road safety is given an important place here.
Road safety is an issue that must continue to occupy us in the future as well.
I view other points more critically.
I would have liked to see a statement on the Shift model, where more traffic is shifted from roads to rail and waterways.
For this reason, I do not believe that the discussion about Giga-Farms is the best solution for increased sustainability.
Similarly critical is the further liberalization of the railway sector and the opening up of national passenger transport, which should be awaited and reconsidered.
Here, technical harmonization and fair competitive conditions still need to be addressed.

As stated, in this report, I hope that the expectations of the Parliament are expressed here, and that they do not remain a mere pious wish list, but that by 2020 a goal is achieved and our proposals have become reality. Thank you.

My dear colleagues,

It is only twenty years ago that the Central Asian states gained their independence as a result of the dissolution of the Soviet Union.
Emerging from a dictatorship, the establishment of democratic and rule-of-law structures in these states remains a persistent challenge.
Nevertheless, these countries, due to their wealth of natural resources and raw materials, are important trading partners of the EU and its member states.
It is therefore only logical to regulate the EU's relations with these states within the framework of partnership and cooperation agreements.
Partnership and cooperation agreements are intended to facilitate collaboration and promote partnership-based action, but not to lead to unilateral stigmatization.
Child labor, and particularly forced labor of children, is a sadly still prevalent evil in many countries of the world that must be combated.

I would like to point out, however, that in many agriculturally dominated European regions, it was common to extend the school holidays for children during harvest time and give children from farming families the opportunity to help with the harvest, which no one today would label as forced labor.
If, however, there are indications of forced child labor in the cotton harvest in Uzbekistan, consequences must be drawn.

The same consequence must then apply to all other states where child labor still exists, including those states where we pursue economic interests of a completely different magnitude, such as India or China.
We should not apply a double standard here.

Mr. President-in-Office of the Council, Mr. President of the Commission, dear colleagues. I can only add my voice to those in these ranks who have extended their congratulations to the Council Presidency.
In times of difficulty, you were not merely an honest broker, but you were also a European broker.

I believe it was very reassuring to experience this in these challenging times, where we see political movements in several member states that imply to people that they could achieve more on their own than together.
You have placed the common ground at the center.
It was also very refreshing to experience that you, with your clear European agenda, found approval among the people of Poland in the domestic political debate.
That was not entirely straightforward in this context.
and also for that, the utmost respect for what you have achieved.
In this six-month period, we have been able to make significant progress, especially in the area of financial market regulation.

If I may single out just one area that I myself was involved in negotiating, namely the issue of regulation regarding short selling and naked credit default swaps on government bonds, where the Commission did not dare to propose strict regulations, we were confronted with resistance from all sides.

Member States were told that you will not prevail, and where it was successfully achieved, thanks to the Polish Presidency of the Council, to sanction a highly speculative instrument and, where necessary, also to prohibit it, so that we can contribute to greater stability in financial markets.
I would like to expressly thank your Minister of Finance and the State Secretary, who initiated this through a laborious process of discussion between the Parliament and the Council.
This is an example of how one can work together in the interest of security and stability in Europe.
Mr. Vice President, thank you very much for that.
As of yesterday, the new surveillance mechanism for economic imbalances has been in effect.
The specific content regulations are now also available.
Secondly, what developments does the Commission now consider dangerous, and what economic problems does it wish to see corrected?
The Commission considers an annual growth in unit labor costs of more than three percent in the euro area countries to be a problem.
A limit for decreasing wages, however, is not provided.
Inexpensive, dear Commission, does not automatically mean good.
It is not sufficient to encourage member states to achieve prosperity at the expense of their trading partners.
Without investments in education, health, and energy efficiency, we may exploit our workforce to the bone, but we will not create economic success stories this way.
Another example from the Scoreboard: The loss of export market shares is to be monitored and sanctioned.
That is nonsense.
With the increase in global trade, Europe's shares, statistically speaking, inevitably decrease.
The indicator consequently penalizes countries that are already integrated into global trade.
Therefore, we believe that the Commission should withdraw this scoreboard and subject it to a complete overhaul. Thank you.

Madam President, Commissioner, dear colleagues. Firstly, I would like to express my gratitude to our rapporteur and all those who contributed to the report. This is not a routine matter, even though we are addressing competition policy for the fortieth time based on a Commission report.

I would like to express my sincere gratitude to the Commissioner, as the year two thousand and ten was indeed the year in which you were first fully responsible for competition policy, marked by a very comprehensive presentation.

I would like to request, however, as you have just mentioned in your contribution, that we should strive for a certain degree of resolution, especially in the area of aids, public aids in the banking sector.
should come, as due to the new stress test by the European Banking Authority, a new capitalization in the banking sector is already being called for again.
I do not believe that this contributes to the stability of the banking system when we still have a multitude of unanswered or unresolved legacy issues on the one hand.
have and, in fact, are already seeing new cases arise due to the pressure being applied to increase the equity ratio, particularly in the private banking sector.

So then, Commissioner, my urgent request is for a swift solution that also contributes to stabilizing the banking sector in such a way that it can face up to the challenges in the international environment.
The second major topic of diffusion control will continue to occupy us intensively in the coming years.
Here, too, I can only urge the continuation of the clear and transparent approach that the Commission has pursued to date within the framework of merger control.
I believe it is in the interest of all parties involved, especially consumers, for us to ensure in the area of merger control that competition is possible even in larger or different structures.
In that sense, I would like to thank all those who have contributed to this effort. And I hope, Commissioner, that we will soon reach a solution, particularly in the banking sector.

Commissioner, I believe you have just hit the nail on the head by collectively acknowledging that we are capable of launching a third industrial revolution in Europe if we recognize the sustainability opportunities as an industrial opportunity.
Then you also spoke about resources, and that reminds me of a thought that I completely forgot about today.
I indeed forgot the human resources in my office.
Mrs. Philipp, please allow me to say that you have toiled like a horse, achieving wonderful successes. You were a truly leading figure in this matter.
For that, I would like to express my sincere gratitude.
