Mr. President. To ensure freedom of speech in Parliament, one also needs a functioning microphone system.
The button to turn on the microphone has broken on my device.
I would request that a technician restore free speech.
Madam President, Commissioner, esteemed colleagues. It surprises me that we continually need to remind ourselves of what is actually meant by structural and cohesion policy.

Cohesion and structural policy is one of the central policy areas of the European Union, and by definition, it aims to strengthen economic and social cohesion within the Community, with a particular focus on promoting growth and employment in underdeveloped regions.
The necessity and success of cohesion and structural policy have been proven, especially in the years of the crisis.
In many regions, the situation appears even more challenging regarding economic development if these funds were not available.
The implementation of Structural Funds support through operational programs, as already mentioned, is based on these programs, which describe the funding strategy for the respective region.
The European Union, Member States, and regions work in partnership here, thereby creating a genuine European added value.
The success of cohesion and structural policy also depends on the reliability of the programs and the funds made available and committed.

Therefore, I am greatly surprised when, time and again, member states and also, as we now see, the Commission attempt to use Structural Fund resources like a piggy bank for all manner of current policy approaches.

This does not do justice to the purpose and aim of cohesion policy, and moreover, it unsettles the stakeholders in the regions who are already working towards achieving these goals based on long-term strategies and agreements.
Certainly, combating youth unemployment and promoting economic growth are important objectives.
This can only be achieved, however, if the partnership cooperation between the regions, the Member States and the Commission is maintained and if the actors in the regions are involved and remain so.
For only you possess the knowledge of what needs to be done in your regions.
Cohesion and structural policy is the unifying, partnership-based, solidaristic bond of action between the different levels of governance in the European Union.
In it, the solidarity of Europe becomes tangible in the regions, and it should not be recklessly abandoned due to political quick fixes.

Mr. President, Mr. Commissioner. I support the compromise reached in the trilogue, which aims to strengthen the negotiating power of dairy farmers vis-Ã -vis the processing industry, even though I am aware that it does not solve all the problems currently facing dairy farmers in some Member States.
Commissioner Mantzolt already envisaged preferential measures for the creation of producer groups as part of the Common Agricultural Policy (CAP) fifty years ago.
Even in my country, Luxembourg, dairy farming, due to the high proportion of grassland, is the main pillar of our agriculture.
Our farmers have long understood that the best solution is to join together in a cooperative that takes over the processing of the milk itself.
Five Member States voted against the compromise in the Council for precisely this reason, as it does not meet the requirement of being a soft landing instrument.

The European Commission holds the right of initiative when it comes to legislative proposals, and therefore, I would like to urge you to present a legislative proposal to the Council and the European Parliament by 2012 in order to rectify this obvious and costly error in the system.

A linear reduction in the super levy, which is incurred for every kilogram of milk delivered, up to 2015, or the abolition of the fat correction could at least mitigate the negative impacts of the phasing-out regulation without harming the unaffected member states.
The present milk package also serves as a final report of the High Level Group, aimed at ensuring a soft landing for the dairy quota exit.
Astonishingly, milk quotas are not mentioned at any point in this report.
The young and ambitious farmers in Luxembourg and four other member states, who are striving to prepare for the liberalization of the dairy market and to expand their production,
want to be able to compete on the world market after two thousand fifteen, they can only do so by also purchasing additional quotas now, shortly before the end of the milk quota system.
an enormous additional and unnecessary capital expenditure that puts you at a disadvantage compared to your colleagues in twenty-two member states. Thank you.
So, please, Biblecat. One question. Are you aware that we have long had community bonds?
and that the resolution does not speak of Euro Bonds in a blanket manner, but rather of very different options.
And are you aware that not all of these options require a contract amendment?
I find it questionable that you have once again made generalizations about Euro Bonds here.
And precisely the nuanced approach that we have achieved with Ms. Goulart's excellent proposal here should not be abandoned.
I would like to hear a little more nuance in your statements and am curious to hear your thoughts on this.
I will just say briefly, dear colleague Goulart, it is not an evaluation that I have conducted here.
I merely wish to point out that the last Italian government bond issued before Italy adopted the euro carried a yield of ten percent.
And there was no outcry in Italy, and no one said that other countries should take over now.
It was a given that one paid high interest rates.

And now suddenly, after ten years of low interest rates and excessive indebtedness, as money has become cheap for investments as well as for public finances, they want to prolong this through Euro Bonds.
This is a trap from which we cannot escape, and I stand by that.
Mr. President. Commissioner, your response has rather disappointed me.

They apparently want to cling to the old system, where complex negotiations must be conducted for each country, which in turn grants no further access to literature, thus creating no additional opportunities for the blind and visually impaired.
This is all the more sad for me because now the European Union is blocking a step forward at the WIPO, while all other contracting partners would be ready to move forward.
A huge opportunity is being missed here.

You are not fighting here for more rights for copyright holders, but you are fighting against people for whom the Convention on the Rights of Persons with Disabilities is meant to guarantee equal access to cultural goods and ensure their full participation in these cultural goods.
I appeal to you. Please dismantle barriers and agree to a binding contract.

Madam President, dear colleagues. The discussion in this House shows that we essentially represent the full spectrum: on the one hand, those who do not wish for any restrictions, and on the other hand, those who associate any form of immigration with the risk of mass immigration.
These are the two extremes within this house.
I believe that family reunification must be viewed with a great deal of reason and rationality.
On the one hand, there are indeed issues in member states where overly restrictive measures are being taken.
for family reunification should not be burdened with so many obstacles that in the end no one can be reunited at all.
On the other hand, it is entirely justified for Member States to require, for example, language skills, to demand integration, but also to require the willingness to integrate within a state.
Secondly, of course, member states have the right, and we should not set aside these issues, to articulate the problems that arise in family reunification.

If countries like Greece or Malta, or also Romania or Italy, are no longer allowed to articulate the problems they partly face in this context, then I no longer know if we are democratic when we simply ignore problems.
I do not believe that we need another new guideline right now.
We should discuss the problems carefully and then consider how we can eliminate them.
Continuously producing new guidelines does not lead to improved guidelines and their implementation.
We are currently experiencing some implementation issues.

I also fully understand that we first need to come to terms with the fact that we should not be creating yet another new directive and adding to it before we have thoroughly discussed the old directive in all its problematic aspects.
I am in favor of listening to the Member States while also respecting the fundamental right to family reunification.
When we do this with reason and understanding, I also believe that we will find a good path.
Mr. President. "Consider before you think," urges the Polish aphorist StanisÅ‚aw JÃ¼rgelewicz, and this recommendation would also do us good in this Parliament from time to time.
Just weeks after this House adopted a resolution on the Central Asia strategy, which condemned censorship in the Central Asian states, strike events are now also occurring in Jarnao Zend.
in Kazakhstan, without waiting for the results of the ongoing investigations, which are being conducted with international participation, to be reflected.
As much as the dead must be mourned, and the injured and imprisoned in the aftermath of these events have the right to a reckoning with what has occurred, the backgrounds remain opaque.

Even Vladimir Koslov, chairman of the unregistered opposition party ALGA, stated: "That was a group of other people. The riots are not in the interest of the strikers at all, as it only provides a reason to use force against them."
Central Asia expert Arkadi Dubnov also stated, "It is not excluded that parts of the Kazakh opposition living abroad are also involved."
On the other hand, however, it could very well fit into someone's plans in the Kazakh capital Astana to keep the tensions simmering.
Ultimately, Kazakhstan's power elites are already vying for the succession of President Nursultan Nazarbayev.
We had the opportunity to speak with the Kazakh opposition in the presence of the Kazakh ambassador here in the parliament.

UN Special Envoy Miroslav Jenszak announced today that he is impressed by the attention paid to the events in Jana Ozen by the Kazakh government and that it is necessary to uncover the true background of the UN.
We should take the Kazakh authorities at their word, measure them by their actions, but avoid knee-jerk condemnations.
If I understood you correctly, your statement today was yes, the Commission is advocating for the continuation of the food program for the most deprived persons in the European Union.
She will do everything in the near future to also put concrete proposals on the table regarding where exactly the program will be located and how financing will be secured.
I consider this urgently necessary and believe that we bear a joint responsibility to ensure that this food program indeed becomes a reality.
not because I consider it the ultimate solution, but because in my view it is a signal to show people that we still have a fundamental sense of the necessary solidarity with the

the life situations of people in the European Union who, unfortunately, were unable to participate in development and have become the first and greatest victims of the way the crisis has been tackled by the European Union.
I think here of Greece, I think of Spain, I think of other countries where exactly what we do as the European Union, above all at the expense of the poorest, the poor, is felt.
We set a sign, but unfortunately, it is no more.

I therefore believe that it is urgently necessary for us to ensure, not only for the eighteen million people in the European Union who are currently dependent on food aid, that the food supply is secure and sustainable.
We want to continue to prioritize, or indeed first and foremost prioritize, the fight against poverty at the top of our own agenda.
We have not transmitted this signal so far.

From my perspective, this is the crucial point, if we want to make further progress here and if we also want to gain the trust of the citizens of our European Union, that we truly shape a social and solidaristic union.
In that sense, you have our support.
We ourselves, dear colleagues, are also called upon to do something to ensure that the governments that have been blocking must give up this stance.
I believe this is also a form of self-commitment for us.
Esteemed colleague, Mr. Daul, I have been listening to you attentively.
What you are proposing, namely to introduce a growth test for all expenditures in parallel with the subsidiarity test, does in fact mean narrowing the focus to growth objectives.
I would like to know from you how you reconcile this with the claim of a Christian democratic faction that, after all, still pursues goals beyond growth.
It must be generally known that the economy does not give birth to children, does not raise them, and is also unable to provide them with a life in intact nature.
This suggests that the priorities should be changed by the Commission and also by the Council, that they should be reconsidered.
We will, as a faction, examine very closely whether what you presented earlier today indeed constitutes a change in priorities.
So far, the motto has been: First the economy, which needs functioning financial markets.
Initially, the focus was on stabilizing public finances, which meant reducing debt and calming the markets.
Mr. Dohl, who is unfortunately absent at the moment, to him I merely wanted to express that I would approach it in the same manner as Georges Machet.
Although I did not understand his answer, I would disagree with him.
I believe the measures that were initiated were simply wrong.
They were not correct, it was not right to focus exclusively on the recovery of the economy while completely ignoring what happens to the people.
It was not right to prioritize the stability of the euro above all else and say that we don't care at all what happens to the people.
It must be the other way around. First, it's about the people, then we can continue discussing the euro stabilization.

The speculative attacks on Spain drove the interest rates on Spanish government bonds above six percent and thus closer to the interest level at which other countries like Greece, Portugal, or Ireland had sought support from the rescue fund.
The austerity policies imposed on member states by the EU, the ECB, and the IMF, involving drastic reductions in all kinds of public expenditure.
Reductions in wages and pensions, increases in value-added taxes, and much more have burdened citizens with additional costs and have not prevented the renewed spiral.
Severe cuts to government spending exacerbate the downturn, drive up national debt ratios, and this must be our shared understanding.
When Mr Draghi recently stated that the European social model has come to an end, I am glad, Mr Barroso, that you say: No, we in the Commission do not think so.
Then I also expect you to go to Greece, to send your people to Greece and to Portugal, to Ireland, and to carefully register what is happening there.
What happens to the people who are currently fighting for their survival?
What happens or what actions do we take together to finally break the suicide spiral that has taken hold in the most affected debt-ridden countries?
It cannot be that we simply stand by and watch here.
And we will not benefit from social policy programs that will eventually take effect once other measures have succeeded.
We need to act now. Where have your target objectives from the 2020 strategy to combat poverty gone?
What has become of the European Poverty Platform?
It has been set aside.
That was before the crisis.
But now, in the midst of the crisis, people need help, they need support, and they need the European Union to take action.
They need no empty promises.
We need concrete ideas about what should be done now.
If you do that, you will receive the support of my faction.
Support all those who, even within the Commission, have recognized the signs of the times and want to bring about change.
But please do not simply carry on and say that everything will be fine.
There will be nothing left if this continues. I urge you to present a concrete project, a concrete program, outlining how we can actively assist the people in the affected countries right now.
Do something about it.

We will have to do this in our countries to prevent the funds for the ESF in two thousand thirteen or two thousand fourteen until two thousand twenty, or indeed for the other programs, from being cut.
that the member states fulfill their responsibilities.
Dear esteemed colleagues, the current situation of public finances and the economy in Europe leaves no room for a tax policy fairy tale hour.
The situation in the Council is quite straightforward: little progress is made on tax policy proposals.
Why?
because some countries are opposed to further tax cooperation efforts.
They benefit from aggressive tax planning, they are tax havens themselves.
And the treaties clearly stipulate unanimity in tax matters.
Therefore, the EU Commission has repeatedly met with failure in the past with its proposals.

They are being watered down, they are not moving forward, as with the interest rate directive, and in more recent proposals, nothing substantial has been suggested at all, out of preemptive obedience.

Therefore, I ask you, Mr. Schemeter, I know your job is not easy in this regard, change the strategy, propose stringent measures, and then rely on enhanced cooperation to end the blocking position in the Council.
Mr. President, dear colleagues. The proposal on risk-sharing instruments presented here will certainly not prevent a state bankruptcy where it may occur.
But doing something is still better than doing nothing at all.
Extraordinary situations sometimes require extraordinary measures.

The fiscal and debt crisis in certain states has created an extraordinary situation where significant projects and initiatives under cohesion and structural policies can no longer be implemented due to the absence of the banking sector as a financier and the unavailability of private investors.
An extraordinary measure, in my view, is the proposal presented here to create risk-sharing instruments for the continued financing of projects in structural policy.
Instruments of cohesion and structural policy available to countries wishing to make use of these division tools can be employed to financially secure projects already in progress.
I am very grateful to rapporteur Danuta HÃ¼bner, who significantly contributed to refining the Commission's proposal and once again clearly outlined when and how these instruments should be utilized.
I am also of the opinion that these risk-sharing instruments should only be a response to the current situation and cannot set a precedent for the next funding period.
When the last amendment to the regulation on biometric passports in the year two thousand nine required a review after three years and the presentation of four studies, our faction supported this.
and indeed because it had repeatedly expressed great concerns due to data protection reasons and also because of the overestimation of the benefits of biometric data in passports.
The belief in perfect identification, the overestimation of this method as well, and what then results from it, the underestimation of other links in the security chain are truly problematic.
The handling of biometric data is still subject to this great misconception, namely the assumption that it is immutable and the most trustworthy.
This is by no means the case.
Even these data are subject to change over the course of life.
In children, they simply look different than in old age.
And for this reason, too, reliable and serious studies and conclusions drawn from them are necessary.
Counterfeiting continues unabated.
We have now been able to establish this.
as is repeatedly demonstrated in the United Kingdom and other countries, the chips are by no means secure against abuse.
They are cheerfully cracked and can mean permanent damage for those affected.
Standards within the EU are also exceptionally diverse.
The error rate is very high, similar to France and the Netherlands.
Time and again, we must ask ourselves what value biometric data holds when documents can be forged and circulated.
If, therefore, a link in the chain is forged, and the source documents are inconsistent, biometric data will not assist us further.
A final note: The Chaos Computer Club in Germany took only a few minutes to demonstrate a forgery.

For this, the friends from the Chaos Computer Club required the lid of a plastic bottle, some superglue, a digital camera, and a little wood glue. Within a few minutes, they had cracked the chip. That's all there is to the supposed security.
We expect the Commission to present the studies, and of course also the results and the consequences that follow from them. Thank you.
Esteemed Council, the Commission is unfortunately not adequately represented today as I would have wished in respect for Parliament.

As a representative from a region that will be severely affected by the planned changes, namely the Eiffel, after carefully following the debate, I am compelled to ask whether the unfortunately rather inadequate attempt...
unification of criteria for disadvantaged areas truly addresses the needs in these regions, especially since the necessary information for a meaningful and responsible decision is not available here.
Above all, I wonder whether a truly comprehensive impact assessment was carried out.
To do justice to farmers, we need not only biophysical criteria but also socio-economic criteria.

Therefore, I call on the Commission to re-examine these important aspects, allowing sufficient time, independently of the overall package of the CAP reform, and above all, after the necessary documents have been submitted and a careful analysis of the impacts on the criteria has been conducted.
I indeed believe that we must work, also in cooperation with the Asylum Support Office and the Greek authorities, to more quickly identify which persons who have come to Greece may potentially

can also be relocated to other countries within the European Union, because firstly, they can definitely never return to their home country again, and because secondly, they may also possess potential and qualifications that could benefit everyone involved.
In essence, it is also about helping the Greeks to enable registration and identification more quickly, thereby accelerating aid processes.

to repatriate those to their home countries who lack the qualifications or entitlement to remain in Greece or the European Union, as they could have had the opportunity to stay in their own home countries.
Many thanks, Mr. President, Mr. Minister, Madam Commissioner, and also many thanks to the rapporteur for her consistently very dedicated and exemplary work.
Much of the criticism that Sophie Infeld has expressed, I can share, support this, or have partly supported it.
But then there always comes the point where one must assume responsibility.
And for the EPP or for myself, I therefore also claim that we must now deal with realities and cannot retreat into ideological or theoretical positions.
The fact remains that the United States has been collecting PNR data for ten years now, and there has not been a single complaint.
The fact remains that none of us want to be in a position where, even with a rejecting attitude, we are able to stop data traffic altogether.
They had just carried that out.
The fact remains that we do not want air traffic between Europe and the USA to come to a halt.
And it is also a fact that the U.S. has a right to know who is entering their country.
And in my opinion, it is also a fact that the legal services have all verbally expressed to us that this agreement is better than the other agreement, than the alternatives.
Therefore, one must also take responsibility here.
And for this we were also elected.
Responsibility for citizens who would otherwise be left alone, with less protection and fewer rights.
Responsibility for the airlines, which otherwise, as the Commissioner had also pointed out, would be left in a state of absolute legal uncertainty.
Responsibility also for the EU as a contractual partner in matters of data protection and security, but also responsibility for a balanced relationship between security and data protection.
Therefore, all things considered, and acknowledging that this agreement is not perfect, we are in favor of approving it due to its consequential benefits.
If one wishes to better protect citizens and provide them with improved data protection, one assumes this responsibility here as well and agrees to this agreement. Thank you.
Mr. President, Mr. Commissioner. The explanations you provided us with were enlightening.
Sincere thanks for that.

Numbers often speak louder than words, and to date, the European Parliamentâ€”as you have mentionedâ€”and the European Patent Office have granted nearly two patents on plants and almost twelve patents on animals, which were created with and without the use of genetic engineering.
I may mention two outstanding examples: the granting of patents on genetically modified and breed-modified barley. This applies to the entire chain from seed to plant.
Affected are our farmers just as much as our brewers, producers, and indeed, we as consumers.
And this example, in my opinion, demonstrates a devastating extent of patenting.
Second example, the so-called Longlife Tomato, not to be confused with its Longlife Oil, which you have in your diesel engines.
With this trick by the applicant US corporation Arcadia, this patent was obtained in violation of valid EU rules.
What was patented was not the tomato itself, but its genetic material, specifically selected enzymes.

This reveals the trick being employed and the fact that, despite your assertion, Commissioner, it is clearly stated in Article 4 of the Biopatents Directive of 1998 that plant varieties and animal breeds, as well as essentially biological processes for the production of plants or animals, are not patentable.
We are of the opinion that this definition needs to be clarified, it must be interpreted more precisely.
Technical methods employed to support conventional breeding must not result in patentability as a whole.
We specifically say no patents on life.
And we need a clear signal here for more ethics and more honesty in dealing with creation, once again against the patenting of life across Europe.
Therefore, Commissioner, we are calling for a clear statement from the Commission that patents on breeding material and genetic resources are and remain prohibited in Europe.
Secondly, we demand a clear stance on Article four of the Biopatent Directive: no patents on life.
Thirdly, Commissioner, on behalf of many farmers and breeders in Europe, we call for a clear enshrining of the breeder and farmer privilege across all legislation. Thank you.
Madam Chair, I would like to address the dismissal of Europol and Eurojust.
To Europol: There is little to nothing to criticize here.

The annual financial statement reflects the financial position in two thousand ten in all material aspects, and all underlying transactions are in compliance with regulations and therefore also lawful.
Notable are only the high transfers in relation to the overall actually low incurred costs.
Europol attributes this to the move to a new headquarters, which is of course understandable.
But Europol undertakes to take further measures in the future to avoid such high transfers.
In addition, Europol intends to commit to monitoring the implementation of the budget on a monthly basis starting in two thousand twelve.
I recommend that we monitor this to see if it actually happens.
Against this background, I recommend discharging Europol.
Regarding Eurojust: The annual financial statement also reflects the financial situation in two thousand ten in all essential aspects.
All transactions here are also legal and in accordance with regulations.
But even here, high operating expenses were carried over into the year 2011.
According to Eurojust, this was primarily due to an organizational structure project for a new computer infrastructure and costs related to data processing.
It is announced that everything will be improved in the future, including better compliance with tender requirements.
I also recommend that we review this in the future and, above all, verify whether all open positions will indeed be filled.
This has been improved.
But if these positions are not filled soon, we would almost have to consider cutting funds, and that would be detrimental to AURIUS.
I still recommend relief.
Madam President, highly esteemed Commissioner, ladies and gentlemen. What should alarm and panic us is not merely the sheer number of unemployed youth in Europe, but the trend.
From two thousand eight to two thousand eleven, the number of youth unemployed increased by twenty-six point five percent, according to the International Labour Organization.
It is this development that urgently requires action. For we are not only disconnecting an entire generation from the labor market, we are disconnecting an entire generation from a livable future.
If we instill in young people a sense of absolute uselessness, we should not be surprised that they are turning away from this EU, as they lack reasonable prospects for work and life.

Commissioner, I urgently request that you ensure decisive countermeasures are taken. I already see some action, but please make sure that the long-standing intellectual stagnation does not now turn into operational panic.

When I read that the Commission is launching a program whereby young people applying abroad are now also to be financially supported, we are merely creating a traveling circus that does not address the problem.
On the contrary, it becomes counterproductive, as technicians, doctors, engineers, and nursing staff are then poached by richer countries that are not in this crisis.
In this crisis, which is the cause of this development, offensive measures are now needed: namely, the dismantling of this austerity mania, which is hampering the economy in Europe.
We need a targeted growth policy, we need to strengthen domestic purchasing power, public investments in education, research, and alternative energies.
That would be the way.
With the combination of European funding, it would then be possible to develop an integrated concept that provides young people with a perspective for life.
Final remark: It is also unacceptable, given this youth unemployment rate, to consider raising the retirement age for people to seventy.
We need a different policy that provides young people with access to the labor market.
Therefore, I urgently request your thanks.
Colleague, you just stated that everything in favor of a financial transaction tax is speculation, and then you yourself presented highly speculative examples.

I would like to know your opinion, in light of your previous statements, on these investigations by the Commission, which very clearly emphasize that, up until now, the real economy and its dependence on [the financial sector/external factors/etc.] have been inadvertently underestimated.

the financial markets, that thus ninety-five percent of companies are by no means dependent on borrowing money, and that one can indeed turn the negative growth effect, previously discussed, into a positive one by making corresponding growth-promoting public investments.
Is this for you merely speculation, or would you argue that such a comprehensive, wide-ranging study by the Commission is also justified and constitutes a strong argument?

Colleagues,

The financial transaction tax is certainly not identical to the Tobin tax, which has been under discussion for many years, but I believe it incorporates essential elements of the Tobin tax.
It at least takes up the idea of involving the financial markets in taxation and, above all, in the costs of the crisis.
I believe this is a very important signal to the financial markets.
This is also a very important signal to the citizens, to our voters.
There were a whole series of actions, petitions, and written initiatives to politicians in a number of member countries, urging the introduction of a financial transaction tax at the European level.
I believe that Parliament has achieved a great success with the majority that is evident here in support of this report and this tax.
Certainly, this is not sufficient to stabilize and restrict the financial markets as might be necessary, but I believe it is a truly important step that has been taken here.
I would like to explicitly appeal to the Council to take the voices of citizens and voters seriously and to advocate for them.
that there is a genuine introduction, that the introduction of this tax is not blocked in the Council due to the British position or other positions.
I believe it is clear that the citizens of the European Union want this tax, and I think it is a great responsibility.

It is now in the hands of the Council to take action here, and I would like to use my speaking time to appeal to the Council to do everything in its power to ensure that this tax is actually implemented and becomes a reality.
Madam President, dear colleagues. I believe that, amidst all the specific issues, which we can and should discuss further in the legislative process, we should be clear about one thing:
be clear. Financial markets cannot operate on a model where banks reap the profits when all goes well, and taxpayers are left holding the bag when things go wrong.
And that is why it makes sense to subject financial transactions to taxation.
And it makes sense to do this across borders.

In Europe, or at least within the eurozone, we would not be facing disruptions, but rather consistently contributing to establishing a stable financial center that generates what financial hubs are intended to produce: namely, enabling companies

Having access to capital in a way that allows savers to put something aside or to save for their old age, and that thus enables financial markets to fulfill the task they were once created for: to generate added value for the real economy.
All of the factors that drove us into the financial crisis were products that did not create value for the real economy.

Therefore, it makes sense to contribute, through taxation, to ensuring that this is heavily penalized, that it is sanctioned, that it is regulated, in the sense that capital once again fulfills its task.
That is why I advocate for us to adopt this proposal by a large majority today.
The reform of the general system of preferences was indeed necessary.
It is now beneficial that there are longer terms and that there is increased security for exporters.
However, the criteria are too imprecise, as the Development Committee has also stated.
Unfortunately, the Commission only refers to World Bank classification.
In the past, the Parliament has repeatedly engaged in a very critical examination of gross domestic product as the sole criterion.
The definition of upper-middle-income countries can refer to countries with a gross national product of four to twelve dollars.
This is thus an enormous and far too wide range, and it in no way reflects the realities on the ground.
We certainly do not find it concerning that countries like Saudi Arabia and Kuwait are excluded.
The reform in this respect was therefore good.
But these countries are high-income countries anyway.
Russia and China are upper-middle-income countries, whose graduation from LDC status we certainly do not need to worry about either.
But this category of countries also includes much poorer nations, such as Namibia and Ecuador.
Until now, the Commission has also at least considered the vulnerability criterion, including countries that export little or only a very limited range of goods.
This at least helps to prevent countries that are less dependent on the export of a few products and are thus very vulnerable from being overrated.
Why then did the Commission delete this criterion?
Countries such as the Dominican Republic, Fiji Islands, Gabon, and Botswana will thus be excluded, even though their economies fall under the vulnerability criterion.
Why did the Commission not continue using the old criteria, which were already somewhat inadequate?
There is a suspicion that the Commission aims to coerce poorer countries into accepting less favorable free trade agreements.
The preference system, however, is an instrument to promote development and cannot be replaced by pure trade instruments in which the development path of a country or region no longer plays any role.
Fortunately, however, there will still be an opportunity for colleagues in the plenary to support our amendment, which includes vulnerability as a criterion.
The new regulation also leads to the disruption of trade regions.
Neighboring countries in customs unions will soon have to follow different rules when exporting to the EU.
This has nothing to do with our goal of regional integration.
The Commission should focus more on development regions rather than individual countries.
Here, too, the Greens have tabled an amendment which, hopefully, will receive widespread support.
It is likewise problematic when countries that only yesterday benefited from the APS are suddenly to be excluded from the program overnight.
Transition periods are necessary, and that a few months are not enough for economic development, we see in our own countries.

Ultimately, we representatives must also consider whether we want to rely solely on speed in all legislative initiatives and then work with hasty compromises, or whether we would prefer to involve the entire plenary.
I believe that the entire parliament is important for legislation, as is democracy, and it is not a question of time or speed. Rather, it takes time and democracy to properly pass laws. Thank you.

Mr. President, High Representative. I was also a member of the European Parliament's election observer mission in the Democratic Republic of Congo and was able to witness the immense hope and anticipation for a better future that the people stood in line with at the polling stations, waiting to cast their votes.
We know today that these expectations were not fulfilled.
Although the Congo calls itself democratic, these elections were neither fair nor democratic.
We must address this proactively, as colleague Nedelcheva also did in her report.
The previous President, Joseph Kabila, has declared himself the election winner. The opposition is being suppressed.
In the east of the country, violent clashes between government forces and so-called rebels have flared up again, and it remains unclear whether third states like Rwanda are involved.
The victims in every case are the civilian population, who have been unable to live in peace and tranquility for decades now.
The wealth of the country is squandered in a quagmire of corruption, leaving the Congo consistently ranked among the lowest in all international assessments.

The international community of states, and here in particular the European Union with its capabilities, must increase pressure on the President of the Republic of Congo to allow genuine democracy in his country. He will have the opportunity to do so in the upcoming regional elections.

to ensure that the Congolese army does not also harass the civilian population, but finally apprehends internationally sought criminals against humanity like Bosco and Daganga and brings them to justice.
Internationally, all states should finally commit to no longer supplying any more weapons to the Congo.
Without external pressure, human suffering and poverty in this country will not end.
Madam President. The Tupac mechanism aims to establish additional intervention rights against crisis-ridden countries in the Eurozone.
The European Semester, established as a framework for necessary and improved coordination of financial and economic policies, is set to be given more teeth.
According to the Commission's intent, member states should be able to be compelled to accept financial aid.
The Six-Pack has already established extensive sanctioning measures that can be imposed on Eurozone states facing financial difficulties.
The European Semester is already perceived by citizens more as a dismantling of democracy than as a meaningful economic policy coordination tool.
At the same time, the German government openly threatens Greek citizens with expulsion from the Eurozone should they make the wrong decision in Sunday's election.
Why don't we stop these humiliating and undemocratic threats?
In a situation where the euro crisis has once again dramatically intensified, thinking of Spain, of Cyprus, it does not help us to put member countries in crisis on the pillory.
We should finally develop solutions. The rapporteurs of Tupac have certainly developed meaningful approaches to this end.
Certainly, Elisa Ferreira's suggestion of a redemption fund is noteworthy. This would be a worthwhile and meaningful measure to combat debt.
Perhaps also the proposal by Jean Paul Gauzet for an orderly state insolvency.
Central, however, is that Europe undertakes a joint and solidaristic effort to put the Eurozone back on a growth path.
The strong countries in Europe must stop being self-satisfied and pointing the finger at their partner countries.
You must start doing your homework, invest in growth, and take on your responsibilities.
Unilateral austerity policies Ã  la Merkel have simply failed as a crisis solution.
Mr. President, esteemed Commissioner, dear colleagues. In June 2010, the EU heads of government finally recognized that the European Community needs a more coordinated financial and economic policy.
On the summit, you essentially invented the European Semester.
It is entirely correct that members of an economic and monetary union must not only consider how their policies affect businesses, employees, and consumers within their own country.
A European perspective is necessary.
A single market without coordination in economic, wage, and social policy presents member states with a strong temptation to create short-term growth and jobs at the expense of their neighbors.
Such imbalances can economically, but also politically, bring the currency union to the point of collapse.
The EU currently finds itself in precisely such a situation.

The German economy has undercut its neighbors for years, providing no impetus through investment and wage growth. Instead, Berlin has driven the eurozone to the brink of ruin with a decade of aggressive export policy.
Therefore, it is encouraging that the Commission is gradually addressing this core issue of the euro crisis in its country-specific recommendations and providing appropriate suggestions.

Quite rightly, the Federal Republic is being called upon to invest more in education, research, and childcare, and quite rightly the Commission is being asked to stop the abuse of mini-jobs and to align wage growth with productivity growth.
This is a late but important realization.
I hope, Commissioner Rehn, that you will strongly advocate this demand to the German government, even though there is no formal procedure for surplus countries.

Mr. President, Mr. Commissioner, esteemed ladies and gentlemen, colleagues. Firstly, I would like to express my gratitude to the Commission, particularly Mr. Commissioner Barnier, for the very simple reason that the experiences from the last legislative period, prior to two thousand and nine,

was, with the exception of a very brief moment of awakening when the proposal for a European private company was put forward, the predecessor of Mr Barnier, Commissioner McCreevy, allowed company law to slip into a deep sleep. Over these five years, we have neglected this important issue, which is also relevant to the internal market.
have made progress.
Thank God, that has changed fundamentally.

Meanwhile, there are a plethora of consultation documents from the European Commission, an expert group that has been developed to address the issue of further developing company law, and we now have a very recent consultation with which we as Parliament, of course, also engage.
The Legal Affairs Committee has decided that we do not wish to do this in the form of a report, simply because a report would require additional time and, of course, would be somewhat more detailed.

We have chosen the means of an oral question to the Commission in order to discuss this issue with the Commission, with Mr Commissioner Barnier, and at the same time to make our position as Parliament clear, in a subsequent resolution, on what should happen now.
I believe that it is necessary, much like we did about ten years ago, to develop a new action plan for European company law, and this for a variety of reasons.
There are gaps within European company law, real gaps that essentially result in the internal market not being achieved.
I would like to cite as an example the absence of the fourteenth directive on the transfer of headquarters, which in my opinion is a quintessential instance of such a gap.
The Parliament has twice called for concrete proposals from the European Commission on this matter in its legislative initiative reports.
There is also the expert panel, convened by the European Commission itself, which likewise held the same view on this matter.
It simply belongs to the fundamental freedoms of the internal market that a company must be able to move within the internal market with regard to its registered seat as well.
This possibility does not exist today, or only under extremely difficult conditions.

Against this backdrop, I must also criticize the fact that the European Commission's current position on the fourteenth directive falls significantly short of the Parliament's expectations and, in our view, does not meet the standard of a qualified response to a legislative initiative.
But we are optimistic that, as work progresses and if the action plan is adopted, this proposal will hopefully be included in the action plan after all.
Another important aspect of company law is the question of its further development with the aim of reducing burdens on companies.
Here we already have very concrete proposals from the Commission on the table, for example on the topic of...
But I believe that beyond this, there is also more to be done and further aspects that will now be clarified in the context of the consultation.
Here we likewise expect further proposals from the Commission.
I would also like to ask the Commission to revive the topic of the European Private Company, which is currently stuck in the Council.
If there are individual member states within the EU that, due to a lack of their own resolve, are unable to break the deadlock on their own, I must state this here based on my personal opinion,

To advance Europe, one must also consider, as with other initiatives such as patents or family law, utilizing the instrument of enhanced cooperation, so that at least all other Europeans have the opportunity to benefit from this possibility.
I would ask the Commission to give this matter more thoughtful consideration.
Another open issue is the question of applicable law, essentially a kind of Rome Regulation for cross-border matters in company law.
I also believe that this question requires further investigation and discussion, and I would ask the Commission to do so.
This is closely related.
We have the insolvency law, but it has already been announced that we will receive a concrete proposal from the European Commission in the foreseeable future.
You see, there is an enormous amount to be done in company law.

I am grateful that Commissioner Barnier has taken the initiative here and that it is evident that we will receive significant proposals in the second half of this legislative period, which can then also represent progress in shaping the internal market.
The parliament supports this in principle and in approach.
Of course, we will still have to clarify the details. We certainly need to do that.
But for that, I also need to thank the Commission.
We would, of course, be delighted if the Commission were to take up our initiatives and translate them into concrete proposals.
Dear Commissioner, I highly value your proposal regarding productivity-oriented wage policy.
But on the issue of the minimum wage, you caved to Mrs. Merkel, and I don't believe you on the question of job creation in the healthcare sector.
How, please, is new work to be created there when the Commission has already forced southern and eastern member states to reduce their hospital capacities by up to half?

How is employment in the health sector supposed to be created when the Commission, in its new country-specific recommendations for the European Semester, is compelling some member states to further reduce their health expenditures?
I fear that this point in this plan is pure announcement politics, not a genuine initiative for new work.
On the contrary, due to austerity measures, there is already a shortage of remedies and medications not only in Greece.

I believe that those who continually roll out new bailout packages for banks must now advocate for a bailout package for the people, especially to secure medical care in the crisis-hit countries. Thank you.
The mood among ill-fated pro-Europeans like me is one of frightened horror at what is currently happening in Europe.
It is at least encouraging that what we are dealing with is now being stated much more clearly, and that Italy's role is also not being overlooked.
You yourself know that you are caught in a series of traps, not just those of debt and growth, but also the trap of trust and the power trap, esteemed Commission and also the Council.
Unfortunately, you have so far failed to address the central question of separating the financial sector from the real economy.
Everything we have decided here, according to expert opinion, is continually being re-evaluated, and no serious limits have been set on the shadow banking system.
Furthermore, we are still faced with systemic risks, the issue of 'too big to fail' remains unaddressed, and there is little need to dwell on the credit rating agencies.
I can only urge and advise you, as you work towards the Council summit, to restore credibility in Europe by seriously addressing the question of power between the real and financial economies.
In a nutshell, you are finally working credibly before the Europeans to ensure that banks are reined in and citizens are not always left to bear the burdens.
Colleague FÃ¤rm, you come from a country that rejected the euro, primarily because it wished to retain the flexibility of devaluation, especially for the purpose of social policy instruments.

In light of the experiences you have now gained in Sweden, would you recommend that the Greeks also leave the eurozone in order to be able to actively employ this socio-political instrument of devaluations accordingly?
Many thanks, Mr. President. I would also like to express my sincere gratitude to the shadow rapporteurs and the rapporteur.
We adopted this report in the Environment Committee with a comfortable majority of sixty-two votes, with no votes against and no abstentions.
This demonstrates that we are in fact in very close agreement on many points, including when it comes to compromises.

And the highest priority in this legislative process must, of course, be a high level of protection, a high degree of consumer protection, especially for the youngest members of our society, for vulnerable children.
As far as gluten intolerance is concerned, this is a problem, and specifically also in kindergartens.
When one looks around, I have two children of this age, and considering the allergies and intolerances that prevail there, I believe we made the right choice.
We should then also discuss this in the second reading with the Council and the Commission.
I believe that we will then also achieve a good result.

Mr. President. A report about a traffic accident over the weekend, involving a truck driver who fell asleep from exhaustion and drove into the roadside ditch, once again confirmed for me how necessary it is...
a clear and consistent regulation of driving and rest times and their control by means of a digital tachograph is essential for us, for road safety, but also for the drivers themselves.
The digital tachograph represents a certain innovation. It presents new challenges, but also old problems.
The new challenges arise from new possibilities of manipulation that we must also master technically.
The old problems are those that we can observe, so to speak, in the control or lack of control in various member states.
What we are now redefining, in my view, has to take into account primarily that not every time a journey is not recorded, a rest period automatically ensues.
For many drivers, loading and unloading is part of their job, and this, of course, should also be considered working time.
The second problem is that the speed records were removed from the file.
I consider that to be incorrect, for there are also great dangers of accidents here.
We would also like to have weight sensors, and we would also like to have a hotline for reporting fraud, which is anonymous and can be tracked.
What I will also introduce is a motion to include animal transport inspections in this regulation.
I consider this to be important because it, too, must be a central element of our legislation.

Madam President, many people could still be alive today or would not have permanent disabilities if professional medical assistance had been provided quickly enough, namely within the first so-called golden hour, after their accident.
We would be a significant step closer to the Vision Zero.
Well, the eCall system we are discussing today cannot prevent accidents. It also does not relieve anyone of the duty to provide first aid.
It solely serves, in the event of a severe accident, to automatically notify an emergency call center.
He must also establish verbal contact with the accident vehicle to prevent abuse and overload due to minor accidents.
Only once the emergency call has been confirmed, or no one responds anymore, are emergency physicians equipped with scant but life-threatening information sent to the scene of the accident.
Responsibility for the functioning of this rescue chain lies subsidiarily with the Member States.
As long as the sensors integrated into the vehicle do not detect an accident, the eCall system remains dormant, transmitting no signals or data and thus cannot be located.
It is thus also vastly superior to a mobile phone from a data protection perspective.
Only with the automatic sensor-controlled awakening or the conscious manual activation does the system become active.
It then sends a pre-agreed minimum dataset of information to an emergency control center.
Uniform European standards and specifications will ensure that these data are recognized, assessed, and handled as emergency calls upon arrival.
Therefore, member states must also accordingly upgrade and expand their emergency medical service chains.

We want this eCall emergency system to be based on the EU's uniform emergency number 112, to be free of charge for the user, to work everywhere in the EU, and to be compatible with the emergency systems of neighboring third countries.
It should be based on an interoperable, technology-neutral, open system architecture.
Through these, other intelligent public transport services can also be offered later, such as real-time traffic information or the availability of parking spaces.

In recognition of the outstanding achievements of the automotive industry in providing private emergency call systems, these systems are to retain their justification for existence in parallel with the public 112-based eCall.
Users can also opt for such a system based on comprehensive information.
This may also include costs if necessary.
Use of data for workshops, insurance companies, towing services, or other service providers.
A small village in Franconia is known for its good beer. This rhyme highlights a small problem that we have created today.

For if this brewery or the beverage retailer is seven kilometers from my place of residence, I no longer have a chance of him continuing to offer me his goods in the future without having to buy a new tachograph, without there being new bureaucracy.

Therefore, I voted against this resolution today, as I believe we should not place too much of a burden on our small and medium-sized enterprises. There were many positive points that we were able to include, thankfully.
It was planned to accept only a radius of fifty kilometers around a regional provider.
That was completely absurd of the EU Commission.
Thus, one hundred kilometers is just about manageable.
But what if it goes beyond that?
I consider it exaggerated.
And one final aspect: as a representative of a labor organization in the CSU, I also say that with this regulation, we are creating complete control over employees.
Why?
because, for example, the person who offers their goods for construction or beverages, for breweries, is monitored throughout the entire workday via GPS.
Therefore, I also consider what we have decided today to be highly questionable from a data protection perspective, and I would like to emphasize once again why I voted against it.
Sincere thanks for this question.
why I am not waiting for this decision.

I awaited the consent of the European People's Party in the Legal Affairs Committee when we were still raising the necessary questions regarding legal certainty with respect to ACTA during the process.
And there was silence in the forest and refusal.
You did not want that. Now it is obvious that the ECJ is to be used for delay, that is clear.
why I said that with the wide margin for interpretation.
Because you have asked two questions, I must unfortunately answer both. That's just how it is.
because one can indeed read into these broad formulations the surveillance of the internet, where auxiliary police officers, the ISPs, can interpret everything in and out.
And that means legal uncertainty. Legal uncertainty also does not help our economy, dear colleagues.
Mr. Leichtfried, I would like to ask you: Are you in favor of discussing the modernization of copyright at the European level?
or are you completely opposed to the rejection of any intellectual property?
And how do you envision the ECOMMERCE Directive being adapted to modern circumstances in the future?
From your statement, I gather that you reject a debate on these matters altogether and do not support intellectual property.
Is that correct, or how do I see it?
Mr. President. The issue at hand is not about individual facts that we need to discuss, but rather the fundamental question: How do we stand on democracy and civil liberties?
Let's take a look at ACTA, and we find that it stands symbolically for lack of transparency, absence of democracy, and violation of fundamental rights, because it was negotiated in secret.
and were undemocratic in a sense, because the free use of the internet might no longer be possible afterward, nor the freedom to utilize generics to the same extent as before.
These are the reasons why millions of people took to the streets and effectively voted against ACTA long ago.
Yes, there has been voting on ACTA in the streets, on the internet, and in relation to the Petitions Committee in many countries, not only within the EU but also beyond.
Even outside the EU. We must not ignore this vote. It is a vote of direct democracy by many citizens who elected us.
I can only advise you to put ACTA to rest, that would be the decent thing to do.

Madam President, Madam President-in-Office of the Council. As rapporteur for the Committee on Budgets and the Committee on Budgetary Control, I have concluded two procedures under your presidency concerning the Financial Regulation. This provides a set of rules for the upcoming MFF period and the OLAF procedure.
Since November 2008, this regulation has been pending in the Council, and you have brought this process to a conclusion based on the results of the Polish presidency.
I would like to thank you for two truly highly committed financial officials who have worked on these dossiers, as well as Ambassador Trankommsen.
I will miss him. His efficiency as a negotiator will be missed by all of us.
They have truly served the financial interests of the European Union.
Sincere thanks.
Mr. President, esteemed ladies and gentlemen. I am speaking here as a representative of my group and would like to support the motion put forward by my colleague, Mr. Fjellner.
Ladies and gentlemen, we do not have many raw materials in Europe.
The raw material we have here is our brain and our creativity.
This necessitates a careful approach to the topic of intellectual property rights.
The European Commission, in order to clarify still outstanding questions, has submitted this proposal, which it has presented to us, to the European Court of Justice for an advisory opinion.
I believe it is only respectful to the highest court of the European Union that we await this decision.
There is absolutely no substantive reason to make this decision today.
No one is prevented from voting against it once the court has presented its decision and opinion.
But the decision that is then made takes place in a different consciousness, in a different understanding than today.
I do not believe that those who travel the wrong way on the internet highway should dictate our policies, and that is why I ask for your support in this motion. Thank you.
As always when colleague Turmes speaks, it is very insightful, and one wishes that what he says would have much more influence on European politics.
I intended to follow up on that.
Of course, these project bonds are a sensible approach, but only if they are oriented towards sustainability and if political frameworks are also established for this purpose.
We run the risk of using guarantees to secure risks that we do not politically control.

Specifically, the energy transition in Germany would require a network of 3,800 kilometers of transmission lines; however, only 100 kilometers of these high-voltage power lines have been constructed so far. This is partly due to resistance from citizens, interestingly, those who are very environmentally conscious.
We need to come up with something from the realm of politics.
One idea would be for us to create shared TEN corridors, combining not only high-speed rail tracks and broadband networks, but also, potentially, constructing overhead power grids alongside highways.
This, however, requires a much more comprehensive planning effort than has been foreseen thus far, but I would like to at least suggest this at this point.

Mr. President, dear colleagues. I consider Schengen to be one of the greatest achievements in the European Union. However, I am also aware that the borders of a country are always a very sensitive issue for our member states, and will always remain so.
I am aware that the issues between member states regarding Schengen cannot simply be ignored.
Various problems exist.
By ignoring, one does not make problems better, nor does one solve them better.
I live on the border with the Czech Republic, and no one in our area would consider wanting to close the border again just because we are facing issues.
But I also ask the Commission for support in this area, not for restrictions and reprimands.
The dragnet surveillance has been implemented to ensure security while maintaining freedom of movement.
And if we successfully carry out the border controls, I assume that at the borders with the Czech Republic as well, where not just a few but many drug dealers will be caught.

In many cases, when they attempt to create a transition, I believe it is beneficial for the German Federal Minister of the Interior and the Czech counterpart to meet and jointly address the issues existing at the border.
The Commission should not regulate in this area but rather positively influence it in a supportive and corresponding manner.

We aim to put the populists in their place but to solve the real problems together. That is why I also ask the Council to seek a solution together with the Parliament so that we can successfully adopt the Schengen files, ensuring that we have freedom of movement while guaranteeing the security of citizens.

Madam President. The instances of disproportionate border controls listed by the Parliament in its question also illustrate why the Council essentially wants to keep the Parliament out of the Schengen matter.
The Council, in fact, continues to undermine freedom of movement without involving Parliament or any form of parliamentary oversight, and without any public scrutiny.
No wonder, then, that you prefer to pat each other on the back in backrooms, away from uncomfortable questions.
No wonder the German government wants to completely rule out an evaluation of internal borders without assessment, and thus doesn't want to examine how much freedom of movement is restricted.
Schengen does not belong to the governments, but to the people of Europe, and thus also belongs in the European Parliament. Thank you.
Mr. President, it is a special moment for me and my political group today to be able to welcome you here in your capacity as President of the Council of the European Union.
And we are also pleased that, for the first time in the history of the European Union, a person stands at the helm of the EU whom we count among our political family.
You are assuming the presidency at a time when the European Union faces immense challenges, and it is crucial to set the course for whether the European Union
whether the Union will indeed have a future or whether it will prove to be, and this would be, in my view, an historic defeat, a mere footnote in history.

After the conversations we have had with you, with the representatives of your government, with the chairpersons of the parliamentary groups and parties in your country, I know that you are preparing for this.
that you have prepared your presidency excellently and that you are also aware of the significance of your task.
But, and you made this clear here today as well, you consciously want to draw the attention of those in power to the living conditions of the people.
I can tell you here, after all I have heard in recent years, this is the first time that a President of the European Union is doing exactly that, announcing it and speaking in this tone.
For a long time, I have missed hearing this in official speeches: It is about the people, about those who are not responsible for us being in this crisis, but who have to bear the greatest burdens.
It will be challenging to implement this precise approach.
I believe, however, that a great deal would already be achieved, and I am very confident that you will do this, if above all you involve people in your presidency and the way you conduct it.
advocate for their rights and ensure that the Council and European institutions are fully aware of this task.
We repeatedly discuss the euro and its stability, the necessity of which I also recognize, as it is important for the functioning of the European Union and the eurozone.
But that is an instrument.
For this, political conditions have been defined.

It can never be the goal of the European Union to accept, for the functioning of the euro, that people in the European Union must go hungry, that healthcare systems collapse, or that local administrations have to cease their operations.
Something has become twisted here.
It is not what we can refer to as the goal of the European Union.
I strongly support your demand that the focus should be on social cohesion and solidarity, both between the individual member states and among the various population groups.
The European Union should not continually allow itself to be used, nor should it present itself, as merely an instrument or spokesperson for a small, specific segment of the population.

And one final point I would also like to address, of course, to emphasize that all of the priorities you have mentioned are important to us, and that we will support the points that align with these priorities, as I have just defined them.
Please do something to ensure that people are no longer afraid.
Fear is the worst advisor for democracies.
I believe that some decisions made in recent weeks and months, particularly during the elections in Greece and the referendum votes in Ireland, were also influenced by fear.
And if those in power in the European Union contribute to people being afraid to make their own free decisions, then that is not a good sign for the future of the European Union.
Best of luck in your work.
Dear colleagues, I believe we have a very important responsibility here, especially as co-rapporteurs working together.
It will be of great importance for the colleague to work diligently and reliably on this dossier in the coming weeks and months.

In this regard, all eyes are currently on us and on the Council to take this step and overcome the banking crisis in Europe through a further step towards Europeanization, namely through a European banking union.
It should be noted that Parliament, with a broad majority, demanded this two years ago.
We have conducted twenty-six trilogues.
We have taken a step in this direction, but unfortunately not as far as would have been truly necessary.
Further billions in charges have arisen as a result.
It is good that the Council has now drawn the consequences and wishes to further deepen this step for the eurozone.
It is commendable that the Commission has developed the proposals so quickly.
However, the Council's decision to make the ECB the supervisor of the euro zone is associated with certain difficulties.
In the Council, this leads to unanimity, and it means that in this file, the Parliament is not involved in the co-decision process.
Based on the experiences with the supervision package, this is not acceptable.

Therefore, it is important that we work swiftly here, but also that we negotiate this proposal on changes to the ECB together with the necessary changes to the existing supervisory regime as a package, thereby effectively establishing the principle of the Parliament's democratic involvement.
Democratically, there are further challenges.
The ECB is independent in monetary policy, but not in fiscal policy, for which it has no responsibilities to date.

If she now becomes responsible for banking supervision, the Parliament needs full budget rights, full oversight rights, questioning rights, and appointment rights. I am confident that the Parliament will also secure these in a broad majority.

The complex issues surrounding the internal market, consumer protection, and the balance between European power and financial responsibility will be thoroughly discussed in the coming weeks. Thank you.
Mr. President. With the proposal to exclude developing countries from preferential market access, the Commission is attempting to coerce these nations into free trade agreements.
These free trade agreements, as the term "economic partnerships" suggests, are solely focused on the interests of the EU and not on the development interests of the partner countries.
This completely runs counter to the EU's objective of reducing poverty and aligning all external policy instruments with this goal.
Countries such as Cameroon, the Ivory Coast, and Namibia would be severely impacted by this restriction.
Regional integration projects, such as those in southeastern Africa, would collapse if Kenya were to enter into such an agreement.
South-South cooperation would come to an end.
We cannot advocate for free trade in the world and merely expect other countries to kindly purchase our goods.
If the Commission truly believes that trade can promote development, then it should not block it.
The Development Committee of this House has recommended rejecting the Commission's proposal.
We should join this in the plenary session.
Mr. President. There are tremendous human rights issues in Central America, as well as in Peru and Colombia.
And we, as EU parliamentarians, cannot simply turn a blind eye to this.
We will thoroughly examine the human rights roadmap requested by the EP in the case of Colombia and Peru once it has been developed.
It must have substance and be binding, and include initial results such as the conviction of perpetrators and the safe return of displaced persons to their country.
And of course, it must also be available before the vote on the agreement.

We Greens believe it is right that the Committee on International Trade is demanding environmental and social standards in the regulatory proposal for the safeguard clauses, and not just tonnage restrictions for bananas.
The trilogue must then also confirm these points, otherwise the regulation is worthless.
The EU must do much more to keep an eye on the situation on the ground and, above all, the impact on the local population.

That is why, as Greens, we demand a proper impact assessment prior to every negotiation, which not only examines the economic implications for the EU but also, and crucially, assesses the impact on human rights.
Mr. Barroso, I had already made clear in the first round what I wanted to emphasize.

My concern is with the expectation of my faction that the Commission should once again fulfill its responsibility within the relevant bodies, making it clear and unambiguous that we, as [a group/faction],

As a commission, as a European institution, we stand for ensuring that people are not driven further into poverty, that working hours are not reduced, and that ecological and social standards are not undermined.
This is your task.

If we succeed in making this clear, we will also send a signal to the people who are protesting in their thousands, hundreds of thousands, in these days, who have taken to the streets, and with whom we as a faction also express solidarity, whether in Thessaloniki or in Barcelona.
This morning, I heard the news that cancer patients in Greece are protesting and going on strike.
Where have we come to that people in deep social and personal distress can no longer receive any help or support because the healthcare system has collapsed?
Here we must finally take action.
And I'll add one more point: An approach held by many in positions of responsibility goes like this: The people in Greece and other states have lived beyond their means.
You must be punished for that today and endure sanctions.
is unfit to strengthen a European community, a community of solidarity.
I am not attributing this to you, Mr. Barroso, but it is an approach that pervades many countries, and unfortunately, it also keeps cropping up in my own country's approach.
Mr. Chairman, I admit I was mistaken.
I would like to make no statement on this report, but rather on the Moreira report on the Agreement on Immediate Autonomous Trade Preferences for Pakistan.
I would like to ask you to call me again.

Madam President. The new directive establishes a framework for handling books, newspapers, artworks, films, musical pieces, and TV productions that are copyright-protected but for which the rights holder cannot be identified or located.
Accordingly, books, films, photos, or other intellectual creations for which no rightful owner can be located should be made available to the public.
and thus a cultural treasure is unearthed.
For us on the Cultural Committee, it was of particular importance in this legislative initiative to emphasize the special significance of the diversity of the cultural heritage of the European Union.

In the archives of our museums, libraries, publishers, and broadcasting institutions, there are countless unused works, and solely because the rights holder is unknown, they have thus far not been made accessible.
This changes with the directive.
In the future, it will enable the use of this cultural asset, provided that a careful search is also carried out prior to its publication.
This is a very important point to prevent the casual statement: "We can't find the copyright holder."
For a balance had to be found between the real, existing rights of the creators of works and the public's need to be able to use such works where the legal situation cannot be clarified.
A particular focus for us was also ensuring that both known and unknown rights holders continue to be fully protected.
And where rights holders cannot be located, the draft enables the use of the digitization of orphaned works.
Projects such as Europeana and other major European digitalization initiatives, as well as our museums, archives, and educational institutions, along with public broadcasting, will thrive.
In the future, it must also be about making the orphaned works in the archives of private publishers accessible to the public as well.
This draft guideline and the compromise that has now been reached, in my view, truly represent a compromise and a first step in the right direction.
I believe that the cultural treasure that exists within it holds immense potential.
We should continue to work on this when we revise the directive in two years' time. Thank you very much.
Mr. Chairman, esteemed Commissioner, President-in-Office of the Council. I would be pleased if we could also include clear provisions in the proposal of two thousand and thirteen.
Signals from the Council would show us how we in Europe can enhance growth and competitiveness potential, and above all, how we can re-employ young people.
Could you please inform us about which budget lines you are promoting youth employment here and placing entrepreneurship and small and medium-sized enterprises at the center?
We know that the ZIP program is the essential prerequisite for this. I only see cuts by the Council here.
or the Erasmus program for young entrepreneurs or the Media Pluralism Program, there are only cuts here.
Do you believe that we can overcome the crisis in Europe by making cuts in areas that guarantee growth and employment?
I have heard that a growth and employment package is being proposed by the Council.
Where can this be found in the household budget presented by the Council?
The Nordseewerke in Emmen were forced to declare insolvency last Wednesday as a guarantee from the Lower Saxon state government was unexpectedly not extended.
This company, with seven hundred qualified jobs, is undergoing a transformation process from a shipyard to a supplier for offshore wind energy.

And now the idea is that this company can be saved through a mass loan and that jobs can also be preserved, because the seven hundred colleagues at SIAC and the Nordseewerke have already had to accept significant wage cuts.

Therefore, I ask the Commission to examine this process with due consideration and promptness, to ensure that these seven jobs are not put at risk, as they are needed to organize the energy transition and to develop future-proof energy sources in the seas of Europe.
Please do not let the colleagues there suffer due to the state government's poor crisis management.
Dual-use goods often appear harmless, but in the hands of authoritarian regimes, they can be as dangerous as machine guns or tanks.
We undermine our foreign policy goals when we send surveillance technologies to authoritarian regimes, enabling them to control and suppress democratic movements.
