It was European mobile phone software from Nokia Siemens Network that played into the hands of Iranian security forces in their suppression of the green protest wave.
Protesters were mass-arrested, detained, tortured, and sentenced to death.
And that is just one example among many.
To add to this, the Commission, with its catalog of measures for innovative and competitive security industries, as it were, promotes these questionable dual-use goods.
The goal is to achieve what is described as a better utilization of synergies between security and defense technologies.
We risk literally selling out human rights, as well as our security interests, for the sake of a questionable industrial policy.
Therefore, I would like to ask you to support our amendments, as well as those of the Social Democrats and ALDE.
I would like to ask Ms. Regner: What do you think unions could do to combat youth unemployment, for example in Spain and Portugal?
Demonstrations will not be enough.
What active role could the internal market play here?
Mr. President, Mr. Commissioner, dear colleagues. I believe that with today's debate on MiFID, we are addressing the core area of financial market regulation.
in this legislative period have made progress, it is about regulating financial markets and not just looking at individual products, as we have done in the past.
I just want to mention a few keywords.
We didn't exactly make our work together easy last year.

We held a hearing in committee, we conducted a consultation with all stakeholders, all interested groups, and on that basis, we developed a result with various processes, working documents, and the like, which we will present to the plenary for voting today and tomorrow.
I want to highlight a few points.
Topic number one: Market structure.

We must, of course, acknowledge on the one hand that a great deal has happened in recent years in the area of financial markets. It is in our interest as a parliament that every trade in financial securities that takes place does so within the MiFID rules, which is why we also agree under many conditions to a new category.

that have agreed to the so-called Organized Trading Facilities, where only non-equities are to be traded, where proprietary trading is to be prohibited, and where, with regard to execution and transactions and customer interaction, corresponding execution at the discretion of the firm can take place.
I believe that we are making an important contribution to ensuring that the entire range of OTC papers that are traded will be traded within the MiFID framework.
Another major topic that was not yet taken into account in the previous MiFID is so-called algorithmic trading or high-frequency trading.
Here, too, our focus was on establishing clear rules, ensuring that this area, which can be highly dangerous and manipulatively employed, is subject to strict regimes with minimum holding periods.

with the ability to interrupt trading, with the possibility of testing algorithms, with the option to review algorithms within a supervisory structure, through the implementation of a so-called tick size regime, a minimum price increment, and corresponding fee systems.
Another topic I would like to address is the area of appointment scheduling markets.

I do believe that we have a special responsibility here when it comes to limiting the speculative element in commodity futures markets so that we do not contribute, through flawed regulations, to a situation where people in the third and fourth worlds can no longer afford to buy food.
We therefore adopted a two-pronged approach, aiming to curb speculation while avoiding harm to the real economy.
We aim to achieve this with position limits, strict caps on the number of contracts or positions.
We also want to ensure, through a so-called Position Check System, that those who can prove they genuinely need a product do not suddenly enter this market speculatively.
Another topic that occupies us greatly is the area of investor protection.
I would like to point out here that we have taken a very broad approach in ensuring consumer protection and investor protection.
The focus here is on identifying the needs of specific customer segments.
Not every small saver needs access to all highly complex securities.

It is about defining relevant products for target groups, conducting product tests, recording telephone conversations, providing appropriate advice, fulfilling disclosure obligations, andâ€”I would also like to briefly mentionâ€”applying subsidiarity in the area of commissions.
Member states should have the possibility, in accordance with their structures, to make appropriate adjustments.
I believe we are on the right track.
Once my time is up, I would like to thank everyone who contributed to this.
I find it regrettable that one only gets four minutes of speaking time for such a complex dossier.
I would like to express my gratitude to all the colleagues who have contributed to this, and to the committee for their highly constructive role over the past few weeks and months.
I hope that with a strong vote from the plenary tomorrow, we will be able to enter into negotiations with the Council in order to finalize this important file as soon as possible. Thank you.
Dear colleagues, first of all, many thanks for the generally good cooperation on this report.
We have a Commission proposal at key points, which has already made significant strides in the right direction, that we can further improve.
In the realm of market structures, there will be increased transparency, particularly a more comprehensive transparency in the area of derivatives trading.
within the framework of MiFID. The decisions on high-frequency trading in our compromise go far beyond what the Commission originally proposed and deserve the support of the Parliament as a whole.
And even on the issues that have sparked significant public criticism, the report points in the right direction.

In the realm of commodity and food speculation, following intense and challenging debates, the new regulations are significantly stronger than the Commission's decisions, as position limits are now set in stone as binding obligations.
We still need further changes in this area, however, in order to close remaining gaps.
I also hope for additions through the plenary vote and ultimately in the trilogue.
It is pleasing that Mr Barnier has already indicated his support for the Parliament's more far-reaching proposal.
Where the report does have weaknesses, however, is in the area of consumer protection.
We now have the possibility to ban products, which is a step forward, but we still have no changes in the area of commission-driven advice.
Even today, the distribution of financial products is not primarily guided by the interests of the customers, but rather strongly influenced by which product offers the highest commissions.
In Germany, and across the EU, consumers have lost significant amounts of money.
Think of the open real estate funds.
For the citizens of France, Italy, Spain, and Germany, unfortunately, not much will change even after our compromise.
The fundamental principle will continue to be performance-based orientation.
Referring to subsidiarity here is a bit simplistic.
I would have liked to see stronger rules here.
Madam President, Commissioner, dear colleagues. Yes, I can only say that what took a long time has finally turned out well.
The report on the type approval of L-category vehicles has ultimately turned out to be a good report after all.
The work took considerably longer than we all thought, and especially longer than we had hoped, and there were far more pitfalls than we ultimately would have liked.
But at this point, I would like to express my sincere thanks once again to the rapporteur, Mr van de Kamp, for the truly cooperative and excellent collaboration.
Together, we were able to achieve a great deal in the negotiations with the member states.
As the rapporteur for my group, I recommend that this report be approved, even though it could have been much improved.
And by "better," esteemed colleagues, I mean "safer."
For us Social Democrats, the safety of vehicles and, consequently, the safety of drivers has always been a top priority, especially the safety of scooter and motorcycle riders.
The number of injured motorcyclists has remained constant for years.
In general, the number of accident fatalities in Europe is declining, but this is not the case for motorcycle accidents.
Reducing the number of fatalities among motorcycle and scooter riders is indeed a matter close to my heart.
Fewer deaths on Europe's roads: this was and remains my goal.
Every death is one too many.
This topic must be thoroughly addressed, especially in a regulation that is so advantageous for the internal market.
That this can be achieved through effective technologies of anti-lock braking systems, namely ABS, I remain convinced.
And I am equally convinced of the cost-effectiveness.
It is simply not true that ABS is too expensive.

What we have achieved, however, is that from two thousand sixteen onwards, all new and from two thousand seventeen onwards, all existing engine types with a displacement of one hundred and twenty-five cubic centimeters or more must be equipped with ABS by the manufacturer as a matter of course.
Motor scooters may be equipped by the manufacturers with ABS or combined braking systems.
At this point, it must unfortunately be acknowledged that we have not achieved any improvements over the Commission's proposal.
I had hoped for much more here, but the Commission and the Member States have, to put it mildly, proven to be extremely sluggish.
What we have achieved, however, is that in two thousand nineteen the Commission presented a report.
The report must be based on traffic accident data from the Member States and is intended to examine the mandatory installation of ABS on motor scooters.
It will also be sent to the Parliament and the Council.
On this basis, the Commission will then consider making the installation of ABS in scooters mandatory.
As you can see, the topic remains very, very alive.
Therefore, we will endeavor to close the binding gap in the legislation starting from two thousand nineteen.
I am confident that the data collected will vindicate my position.
I am convinced that this is indeed a good day for two-wheeled vehicle drivers in Europe and that accident numbers will decrease in the future. Thank you.
There is no technology without risks. There is no perfect energy generation technology.
I believe this also applies to what we are discussing here today.
I am very much in favor of discussing this rationally.
What we are currently experiencing is a new development in energy markets driven by unconventional resources, particularly in natural gas but also in oil.

I believe it is neither appropriate to fall into great euphoria about the grand future, nor is it appropriate, as some of my colleagues from the Greens and the Left have done here, to paint grandiose horror and terror scenarios onto the wall that have absolutely nothing to do with reality.

I believe that we must keep in mind that these unconventional resources have the potential to transform all the energy supply relationships we know between suppliers and demanders, and that the economic calculations of previous energy carriers are also being called into question.
We should face up to this development.

I believe that we should acknowledge that this could also be an opportunity for Europe, and not just a risk. We should prepare to harness and utilize new technologies positively, to fairly assess opportunities and risks, and to avoid falling into ideological debates.
Commissioner, your response does not entirely satisfy me.
For I consider a period of one year between the notification that the complaint has been received and possibly only then receiving a response to be a very long time.
I believe that a complainant who goes to the trouble, and usually they have already exhausted the entire legal process in their member state, deserves more.
We rely on citizens to engage with the European Union.
If you do it in this form, we should also treat you accordingly.

I believe it is necessary and indispensable in the long term that we have a procedure here that is clearly formalized and clearly regulates rights. This is now a declaration of how the Commission intends to handle this.
On another point, I have no objection, if it serves the purpose, to attempting to reach a kind of consensual clarification with the member state.
Only, that will not always be sufficient.
We observe, for instance, that proceedings are relatively swift in economic matters when one company sues another for a violation of EU law.

But when it comes to environmental issues and similar matters, where a very, very large number of citizens demand action from the European Union, or also social rights, then progress is made somewhat more slowly.
I believe that these facts, too, must be taken into account explicitly.
For your next report, I would like to see a clear formalization of the complainant's rights vis-Ã -vis the Commission, which are also genuinely explicit and well-communicated.
If we truly want European law to be applied, after we have gone through so many procedures here in the European Parliament and in the Council,
We have jointly decided on this. We must then inform those who are responsible, those who are truly committed to a European approach, as thoroughly and precisely as possible.
This is of great importance to me.
And I will also carefully observe again next time what has developed here. Thank you.

Mr. President, colleagues,

Five years ago, the EU's Central Asia Strategy was launched.
When we ask about the balance sheet of this strategy today, the assessment is mixed.
We observe how individual member states strive for good economic relations, particularly with the resource-rich countries in this region, while on the other hand, efforts are not progressing.
accompanying them in their transformation process towards modern democratic societies, or as the recent events in Kazakhstan show, the development is even marked by setbacks.

Nevertheless, or precisely for this reason, the European Union and its member states must more strongly express their influence in this region collectively, especially towards Kazakhstan, which has now become a major supplier for several EU states.

An isolation of Kazakhstan by the EU would only result in the competitors for influence in this geopolitically significant country, where the pressure to adhere to civil and human rights is not as important, being able to assert their influence even more strongly than before.
The linking of economic interests with the commitment to upholding civil rights is the central aspect of the Central Asia Strategy.
This should also form the basis for further negotiations on a Partnership and Cooperation Agreement with Kazakhstan.
The present report provides a good orientation in this regard. Sincere thanks.

Madam President. Ladies and gentlemen of the absent Council, perhaps you are following us via the Parliament's video stream, as it is evident that you lack both the capacity and the inclination to engage with us live.
I regard the Council's absence here and today as a grave disrespect to the Parliament.
Instead of dodging this debate, you should rather reveal your secret as to why you resist any improvement in the protection of personal data in the police and judicial sectors through a directive.

Police and justice systems have, we know, been for years a veritable gold mine of data protection violations, not just in the case of SWIFT, but on a daily basis, for example, when data of citizens who demonstrate against Nazis is unlawfully collected and stored.
We need the same protection standards for the public and private sectors and for the police and judiciary in order to be able to guarantee civil rights.
If you, the Council, call on the Parliament to constructively contribute to data protection regulations such as the EU PNA or Europol, then this must surely also apply in reverse to the Council.
Therefore, I call on you: finally put an end to the policy of obstruction in the field of data protection.
